SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In continuing my remarks of last night on the Trade Practices Amendment Bill, I reiterate my absolute support for the proposal contained therein to repeal section 65u which contains a sunset clause on the application of produce safety and product information provisions relating to food and drink for human consumption. As was mentioned yesterday, this clause will take effect on 1 July 1988 unless repealed. Failure to repeal section 65u will render the Commonwealth powerless to recall unsafe food and drink products sold in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members will recall that the Opposition has circulated an amendment to this clause of the Bill which would extend the sunset clause for a further two years, supposedly to provide the States with more time to introduce their own legislation. This cannot be viewed as anything other than a stalling mechanism which may or may not receive the support of the Australian Democrats when the Bill reaches the Senate. Hopefully, the Democrats, who originally proposed the inclusion of this section in the Act two years ago at the behest of the food industry, will now realise that sufficient time has passed for those States which are dinkum about this measure to have introduced it. Even in the unlikely event of all States enacting legislation to cover this area, there would be little prospect of uniformity. There is no uniformity now between Queensland and Western Australia, for instance. National legislation is the only way that all Australian consumers can be adequately and properly protected from the sale of unsafe food and beverages.

Food and drink are essential consumer products which are produced in most States and transported to most others. It is a national enterprise and is not contained within State borders. For instance, except for some localised products, generally of a perishable nature, such as eggs, butter, milk, et cetera, it is difficult to think of processed foods and beverages which would not have a market in more than one State. Even cheese, which is often seen as local, is traded among States and the milk which is used to make the cheese may have been an interstate product as well. Where a safety related recall is required it is generally national in character and national co-ordination is absolutely essential. If section 65u is not repealed, the Federal Government may be unaware of food safety problems and product recall may be conducted on a State-by-State basis, with little or no oversight to ensure that the protection of all consumers in the nation is a priority.

Failure to repeal this section would have the effect of removing foods and beverages from the scope of division 1a of the Act, as I have said, and would effectively remove the Federal Government's power to prevent the supply of unsafe food products. This would mean that we would be unable to prevent the supply of a food product even where it can be demonstrated to be unsafe and a threat to the health and safety of consumers. The States have a legitimate role in food safety, particularly through the Australian food standards code and their own health and food inspection systems.

The honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) made great play of the States rights arguments in his contribution to the debate yesterday. One can almost understand his view on this matter given the excellent record of the South Australian Labor Government on consumer affairs generally. Unfortunately, he totally overlooked the need for national legislation to ensure that life threatening foodstuffs and beverages are not sold in one State after having been banned in another. The reserve ability to protect consumers nationally from defective foods and beverages must remain with the Federal Government under the Trade Practices Act.

The honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) used part of his time in this debate to attack the Australian Consumers Association (ACA) for having the temerity to test foodstuffs and comment on the results obtained in its magazine Choice. Why should the ACA not say that various brands of pate, for instance, contain too many bacteria if that is true and if that is what its tests have shown? Why should it not point out to its constituent group, the consumers of Australia, that preparation, storage and transport of this high protein food must be undertaken in conditions that prohibit the growth of dangerous micro-organisms? As a lover of pate in all its forms, home made and store bought, I took the comments of the ACA seriously when I read them in Choice. Hopefully, so did other consumers of that type of product, and also the manufacturers.

The comments of the honourable member for Ryan against the Australian Consumers Association simply reinforced the view that the Opposition does not care about the rights of consumers, or their hardworking advocates. Although the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) implored us all to believe in the Opposition's basic integrity on consumer issues, the attitude of the honourable member for Ryan tends to bolster a contrary view.

To conclude my remarks on this Bill I would like to make brief mention of another amendment which prohibits false representations of the value of goods or services. The amendment to section 53 provides that a corporation shall not falsely represent that goods or services are of a particular value and it is designed to remove any doubt that this section prohibits false representations as to the value of goods or services. There is a propensity, or appears to be, for cosmetic firms and others to advertise bonus offers of goods said to be of a certain value which can be purchased at a reduced price on the condition of the simultaneous purchase of other items of the same brand. Possibly the worst example of false representation of product value can be seen in the rash of television advertising of pearls and other items of jewellery on mail order basis. The value attributed to many of these items by the advertiser is seldom evident on receipt of the goods by the hapless purchaser, who has very little opportunity of obtaining redress.

I have received a number of complaints about the shoddy nature of such goods and it is obvious that they, and the special offer items which frequently accompany them, are not worth the money paid, let alone the inflated value claimed for them by the advertiser. This type of sales pitch seems to be particularly targeted at women and I suggest to the House that it is an area that has definitely needed overhauling. I commend the Bill, I commend the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and I commend the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), who is currently at the table, the previous Minister for Consumer Affairs. I ask the House to accept this Bill and to reject the Opposition's proposed amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The relatively moderate speech of the honour-able member for Cowan (Ms Jakobsen) and the speech of the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) last night, for those who have been following this debate-most of which took place yesterday-are in considerable contrast to the emotional and falsely rhetorical speeches of the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), who led for the Government in this debate, and the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner). The whole impression that those Government speakers have managed to convey is that the Opposition, the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia, are not supportive of what the Government is trying to do in the field of consumer protection. This is a totally false impression. The Trade Practices Amendment Bill is receiving the support of the Opposition. The public, listening on a broadcast day yesterday, would hardly have got the impression that that is the case. In fact, the Opposition supports the Trade Practices Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a question relating to the second amendment in the Bill which relates to the so-called sunset clause, section 65u of the Act. The Government proposes that this section be repealed. The Opposition proposes that it be va-ried in such a way as to maintain the status quo that currently prevails. As the honourable member for Cowan I am sure would concede, the situation that currently prevails is one in which the Commonwealth does have responsibility. In the areas of product safety, product information standards and the mandatory recall of hazardous goods it has general jurisdiction. The existing sunset clause in the Act provides for that res-ponsibility to cease on 1 July 1988, that is two years after that provision was put into the Act in 1986. The Opposition's amendment proposes that that period be extended to 1 July 1990. The amendment proposes that section 65u be repealed and replaced with a new clause 65u which would read:
On 1 July 1990 this Division shall cease to have effect in respect of goods which are foods and drinks intended for human consumption.

In the interval one would expect that the States will move more specifically and definitely into this area and the matter can then be looked at in 1990. The effect of the Opposition's amendment is that the status quo, the present Federal responsibility which reposes under the Trade Practices Act, continue. So product safety, pro-duct information standards and mandatory recall of hazardous goods would remain within the purview of the Federal Trade Practices Act. The sorts of concerns expressed by the honourable member for Cowan particularly about the purchase of food products, say, in Brisbane and their consumption in Perth and discovery that they were hazardous or inadequate do not apply.

It is clear that what the Opposition is suggesting in this respect is not that responsibility in this area cease but that the existing situation prevail for a further two years. With that aspect of the matter clear and despite all the emotionalism of the honourable member for Capricornia last night and the honourable member for Hughes, we can go on to the other two amendments proposed in this legislation which have the full support of the Opposition.

The first is an amendment that relates to section 53 in division 1 of part V of the Act, consumer protection, and deals with false re-presentations. The amendment proposes to remove any doubts that that section will work to prohibit false representations as to the `value' of goods and services. This is essentially a clarification of the existing prohibition on false representations that goods or services are of a particular standard, quality or grade. So under the proposed addition to the provision, section 53, if a value at some multiple of the real market value is put on a good the issue is whether that is a false representation that the good is of a higher quality or standard that it actually is. Maybe this could be so in isolated or occasional cases and so there may be some scope for affirming that section 53 should prohibit false representations as to the value of goods and services.

The Opposition does not oppose this. I am just set to wondering whether such a provision would have caught up the assertion that Barrie Unsworth is good value-there was a very clear demonstration at the weekend that he was not, or at least that the majority of electors in New South Wales did not think him so! Be that as it may, one may be sceptical about the view that false representation in relation to value or even these other matters would be a pervasive or common occurrence, and certainly where there is effective competition that could hardly be the case.

That brings me to the main point I wish to make in this debate. The part of the Trade Practices Act that we are mainly concerned with, part V, dealing with consumer protection, is not the only nor even the most important way, mechanism, of affording benefit or relief to consumers. We have heard about so-called consumerism. The Liberal and National parties are fully committed to the consumer, every bit as much as the Australian Labor Party professes to be, but they are so committed in the context of their conviction that there is, generally speaking, no conflict between the consumer and the provider in the free enterprise system. The main thrust of our attitude is that we want to free up markets, reduce regulation and encourage competition, in the conviction, as I say, that the effective working of competition in the marketplace provides benefit and protection to the consumer most of the time.

Yet when this debate was listed we saw a long list of Government speakers anxious to wield the stick on the comparatively few cases of malpractice that do come up, and hardly able to restrain themselves from getting into some direct action to control the situation. In some cases that is justified. I submit that the incidence of such malpractice is pretty minute compared with the millions of exchanges, transactions, which take place in the market every day to the complete satisfaction of both buyer and seller. Indeed, the central thrust of the Trade Practices Act as a whole and the way in which the Act contributes most to consumer benefit is not through its consumer protection provisions but through its provisions which foster and strengthen effective competition in the marketplace. The so-called consumer protection provisions are there in the Act, and I stress that no-one in the Opposition is suggesting that they be repealed, reduced or impaired. That is the impression that the Government speakers in this debate have managed to convey, but it is not so. But we do believe that there has been undue emphasis on this and that the central thrust of the Trade Practices Act as a whole has been lost sight of.

I remark in passing that the last time I had any significant involvement with this Act was eight or 10 years ago in the context of the traumas, which are still occurring, in the petrol reselling industry, when there was indiscriminate discounting, dislocation, losses and widespread threats to the continued viability of many small resellers in that industry. I suppose what we had there was both a consumer protection and a fair competition issue. That issue is still with us. Only recently representations were made to me in this regard. I understand that the Trade Practices Commission is presently conducting an investigation into this whole area as it is concerned that the spirit of the measures that were then taken are not being observed. Those measures were, of course, the passing of a petrol reselling franchise Act and a sites Act. The passing of that legislation seemed at that time in the circumstances the most direct way to contain the situation.

The sites Act in particular was a very rigid, specific regulatory measure, actually specifying the number of petrol reselling outlets to be permitted to each of the major oil companies and other wholesale suppliers and providing for their gradual reduction. I mention this because it seems to me that that was a very direct approach to the problem-more consistent with the sort of approach being taken and frequently advocated on the other side. I believe that as the problem is still with us we need to think about a less direct approach which I believe would have been preferable. I accept the need for the franchise Act, but what was basically required in the other area was legislation to deem a wholesale price of petrol in the case of company or commission agent operated sites where the only price was the actual retail price. In the cut and thrust of competition between the major oil companies the retail price is often cut below the wholesale price to other sellers. I believe that the best and most effective way to tackle this problem of only a retail price is to provide for a deemed wholesale price and then to look at the whole situation in terms of undue price discrimination under section 49 of the Trade Practices Act, the price discrimination provision. Then, under that safeguard, the market and open competition can determine the outcome.

Another important way in which consumers can benefit is through privatisation. The Government is in something of a mess over privatisation and perhaps it does not want to talk about it. It is showing up all its factional differences in this area and has elevated the subject to an ideological confrontation. I say that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has only himself to blame for the situation. It was he who not so long ago referred to privatisation as economic and social vandalism, when he said:

What in the name of reason is the justification for breaking up and selling off the great and efficient national assets, like the Commonwealth Bank, Telecom, TAA and Qantas . . . But as the people of Australia come to realise the extent of the economic and social vandalism proposed by our opponents-and indeed as part of the process of promoting that awareness-it will be necessary for us-Ben Chifley's heirs and successors-
this is the Prime Minister speaking-
to keep fresh and green the memory, the example and the experience of this great Australian.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating) for his part has described the coalition's proposals in this regard as a `Thatcherite vandalistic splurge'. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer have had somewhat of a Damascus Road like conversion on this but the only result is total confusion in the Australian Labor Party on the issue. It has contributed to the whole disarray in the Labor Party, which has resulted from disgraced Ministers, jobs for the boys-as exemplified by Mr Young-the sleaze factor in the Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd affair, and so on. The electorate in New South Wales expressed its views decisively on those matters last weekend. What is important is what will benefit consumers. Undoubtedly malpractices will occur which should be attacked by these consumer protection provisions, that members on the Government side have placed great emphasis upon in their contributions. But the important feature of privatisation is that it is not a matter of ideology but of common sense. That has been overlooked.

Privatisation is about asking whether there is a benefit to be had by consumers. Does it reduce the scope for undue political influence? Will it facilitate capital injections, which we all know are urgently required by a number of important public enterprises at the moment such as Australian Airlines and Qantas Airways Ltd? The Government has been constrained by the demands of overall economic policy and indeed has not pushed ahead as quickly as it should in relation to Australia's vast overseas balance of payments problem and massive overseas debt. Under those circumstances the Government is not really in a position to make such provision of capital.

What I am saying is that in contrast to all the fulmination we have heard, particularly from the honourable member for Capricornia, consumers stand to gain more in this area where the Government does not act because it is in such disarray. For example, I refer to the airline industry. The industry should be deregulated, competition injected and privatised. When that happens who could doubt that prices will come down significantly to the lasting benefit of all consumers.

In conclusion I reaffirm that the Liberal Party-National Party coalition is not opposed to the consumer protection provisions of the Trade Practices Act. It is not opposed to the present amendments with the exception that we wish to provide for the extension of the sunset clause as I set it out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) for his interesting although completely irrelevant comments. I shall not seek to argue with him the question of privatisation. I am sure he realises that the views of members on this side of the House are markedly different, as they ought to be, from the views of members of the Opposition. I shall be addressing the issue of intervention in the market in the course of my contribution to the debate. Before turning to the specific nature of the amendments I wish to comment on consumer protection generally. Obviously the amendments relate directly to consumers. It is important to recognise that this Government has amply demonstrated the depth of its commitment to Australian consumers. It was the first government in Australia to establish a ministry for consumer affairs in its own right.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government stands on its record of ensuring that the rights and responsibilities of the consumer and the business community are explained and protected. The Opposition has expressed some grave concerns, dismay and a great amount of angst about the efforts of this Government to protect consumers. They have recently undertaken a series of vitriolic attacks against the Government's price watch structure, headed by the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) They were attacking him and the price watch committee for the revelation of the fees that doctors were charging.

I inform the Opposition of the need for us to protect consumers. After all, the people who seek the services of medical practitioners are consumers. We ought to be aware of some of the things the price watch committee and this Government are concerned about. Honourable members will recall in the debate which was going on some weeks ago about the honourable member for Canning and the role of the price watch committee in addressing the medical profession the outrageous fees that some members of that profession-the minority of that profession-have sought to charge. On 2 March 1988 on the AM program there was an interview with Hilary Russell from Health Call in Victoria and Ken Sleeman, President of the Australian Medical Association (AMA) in Victoria. The interviewer was Laurie Neville. In that interview Peter Thompson, who was introducing the program, said:
Victorian doctors are resorting to the use of debt collectors to recover unpaid fees.

Debt collectors are being used by the medical profession to collect fees. It is not so much the question of the debt collection but why they are using debt collectors and for what purpose they are using them that is of concern. Hilary Russell stated:

. . . there's a marked increase amongst practitioners to charge in excess of the schedule fee and we have many, many complaints where doctors and diagnostic groups have charged up to 100 per cent more than the schedule fee.
Laurie Neville, the interviewer, challenged this and said:
But perhaps doctors have done that and they have simply come to the end of their tether and there's no choice.
Hilary Russell responded by saying:

There is little evidence to show that there's clear communication or information given to patients, prior to a person undergoing a consultation or hospitalisation. It simply hasn't been built in to the way we use and the way in which the health services are provided. Up to 80 per cent of a practitioner's income is subsidised by the public purse.
That is something which seems to be overlooked by the Opposition every time it addresses this question. Then there was a response from the AMA. Ken Sleeman responded:
Well, there's no doubt that accountants tell us that we should be more efficient in our business practice and that's what it is, improved efficiency in business practice.
In other words, they are ripping off the consumers and then getting in debt collectors to retrieve the fees that they have charged exorbitantly.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a load of rubbish.
—The evidence is in front of the honourable member.
—Of course it is not in front of you. You don't even know what you are talking about. What is the schedule fee, you drip?

—I know a great deal more about what I am talking about than the honourable member does. I suggest that he listen to the rest of what I have to say. This Government stands on its record in the area of consumer affairs and consumer protection, much to the chagrin of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). I can assure the honourable member for O'Connor and the honourable member for Berowra that this Government will endeavour to maintain the way in which it approaches the question of consumer protection and ensure that consumers are protected wherever they are and regardless of who they are getting a service from-whether it is doctors, lawyers or other professionals.

SPEECH.PARA: I should like now to address myself in general to the comments made by the honourable member for Berowra in terms of deregulation of the market. When we talk about regulation and enforcement of consumer legislation we are, in effect, talking about the minimisation of harm to individuals. Ralph Nader, perhaps the world's foremost consumer advocate, has said, `Regulation saves lives'. How right he is. In a recent interview Nader claimed that since the passing in the United States Congress of the National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act in 1966 more than 150,000 lives had been saved. I ask those members who are gung ho advocates of deregulation and believe that consumer regulation is merely red tape designed to frustrate the business community and build unwieldly Public Service bureaucracies to consider a world without consumer regulations. There would be no product recalls, no seat belts in motor vehicles, no checks on our children's toys for safety or toxicity, and no safety standards for food additives. In addressing this matter Ralph Nader said:

Regulatory agencies help to protect our long term safety and health: enhance equity in the marketplace: empower consumers and workers: spur new and socially useful technologies: provoke greater academic and journalistic inquiry; and provide some measure of democratic control over privately developed technologies that violate our society's ethical norms.

There is no doubt that consumer regulations restrict some aspects of the free market. But even free market champions such as Adam Smith, in this seminal work entitled The Wealth of Nations, could see the sense in setting limits on what he termed `the simple system of national liberty'. Smith conceded that there were conditions under which the state could and should intervene to correct faults in the system, as I am sure the honourable member for Berowra would acknowledge. I am not seeking to lecture such an eminent person. Mr Smith also allowed that the private sector was not necessarily the best provider of all social and public goods. I am sure that the honourable member for Berowra, especially, is conversant with the following statement-and I hope that the honourable member for O'Connor is, too; if not, he will be shortly-by Mr Smith:
Whenever you get more than two capitalists together there is a conspiracy against the consumer.

The history of the consumer rights movement is littered with stories of rip-offs, fly-by-nighters, deception and unscrupulous business practices. To be fair to the business community, it would not be responsible or just to allow to proliferate from State to State and from Territory to State a series of laws which created a nightmare of differing regulations which produced uncertainty, speculation or added cost. That is why this Government has made it clear that it is committed to having uniform legislation throughout Australia. It is also clear that the general community wants consumer regulation and protection. It has been shown that consumers who are aware of their rights often provide positive feedback to retailers and manufacturers, who can then tailor their services accordingly and offer an improved service or product.

Last week the Trade Practices Commission opened an agency in Darwin which will provide a closer watch on any illegal or unfair trade practices in the Northern Territory. This move is to be highly commended. Previously in the Territory there have been some difficulties in providing advice and keeping people up to date with consumer information. There is no doubt that the agency will give Northern Territory business and consumers alike greater protection, with access to staff trained to advise in trade practice matters. Certainly, the new Darwin agency will contribute to the Commission's ability to enforce the Trade Practices Act in the Territory. I believe that both this Government and the Northern Territory Government are to be commended for the establishment of the agency.

Whilst on the subject of the Northern Territory and the need for consumer awareness and consumer education, I would like to address briefly the matter of consumer education amongst Aboriginal Territorians. To its credit, this Government is in the process of developing, a Consumer education program for Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory. These people are the ones who are ripped off most often by unscrupulous dealers in the marketplace. There are numerous examples of the way in which the business community has used its position in the retail and other industries to exploit the inability of some of my Aboriginal constituents to read and write English or to understand the intricacies of the marketplace.

One of the most outstanding areas in which this happens is in the retailing of second-hand cars. There are numerous examples of people involved in the used car industry in the Northern Territory who have used every trick in the book to exploit my Aboriginal constituents. I am sure that this does not happen just in the Northern Territory. I am sure that it also happens in Western Australia, Queensland and, no doubt, South Australia. It is also true that there are stories of Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory being charged twice the cost for goods in shops. An instance was related to me this morning of a person being instructed by an employer to charge Aboriginal people double the price. That is why consumer protection is needed in this country and why we must look carefully at the way in which members of the business community are addressing the question of providing services to the public.

Whilst we look at the marketplace and the retail industry, it is important that we recognise the role of professionals in that area. I return to what I said at the commencement of my remarks in this debate: it is important that we recognise that there is not a single area of the business community that does not bear scrutiny. I have highlighted the concern expressed by consumers of medical services in Victoria of the need to be wary of the role of some members of the medical profession who use their office and their position, in circumstances where they have overall control of their clients, to demand exorbitant fees. In a recent debate in the House we heard how ophthalmic surgeons or ophthalmologists in the Hunter Valley, and orthopaedic surgeons in Wollongong, were using the system to rip off people in the way I have mentioned. Those are matters that the price watch committee, chaired by the honourable member for Canning, has been seeking to address, much to the chagrin of some members of the Opposition. I am sure that the honourable member for Berowra is not one of those and shares my concern that those people in private enterprise who seek to rip off consumers should be controlled. While we are talking about regulation and deregulation, I suggest to members of the Opposition that the market can be deregulated as much as one likes, but the important thing is to recognise that the marketplace will operate to the best advantage of those who sell commodities. That is what has happened traditionally in this country, and that is why this Government is interested in consumer protection and will fight for the interests of the consumers.

In the time left to me in this debate, I wish to address the main aspects of the Trade Practices Amendment Bill. The purpose of the Bill is to make three amendments to the consumer protection provisions of the Trade Practices Act 1974, each relating to developments since the last major revision of the Act in 1986. This Government attaches great importance to ensuring that the Act is effectively achieving its aim of providing consumers and business people with an appropriate measure of protection against unscrupulous traders-the type of person I have mentioned. The first amendment provides that a corporation-and in some cases an individual-shall not, in trade or commerce, falsely represent that goods or services are of a particular value. This amendment should remove any doubt that section 53 prohibits false representation as to the value of goods or services.

The second amendment proposes the repeal of section 65u of the Act. As the honourable member for Berowra said, that section deals with a sunset clause and the application of the product safety and product information provisions of the Act relating to food and drink for human consumption, which will take effect from 1 July 1988. As the House has been told, this section was originally enacted in the belief that uniform State and Territory legislation would be passed, but unfortunately that has not occurred. I would like to know why that is so. The repeal of section 65u will enable the Commonwealth to coordinate any national safety-related food recall. Without the repeal of this section, the Commonwealth will lose the power to ban the supply of unsafe food and beverages, to set safety or information standards in respect of food and beverages, and to require suppliers to take action to protect consumers from a hazardous food or beverage if voluntary action proves unsatisfactory.

Division 1a of part V of the Act is concerned with product safety standards, the banning of unsafe consumer products, and the recall of consumer products with safety-related defects. It is essential that this nation have a uniform system of food and beverage recall. It is a fact of life that food and beverages are distributed and marketed nationally. For instance, in the Northern Territory one has only to drive along the Stuart Highway from Alice Springs to Darwin and witness the hundreds of road trains which truck in the Territory's food supply to realise that State and Territory borders are meaningless when it comes to food distribution. If there are unscrupulous traders who want to move, from one part of the country to another, products which should have been recalled, without the authorities being informed, they are able to do so. If we are to safeguard the public, it is imperative that we have in place an assured national protection mechanism which provides for a coordinated approach to safety-related food recalls.

In relation to food recalls, what happens now is that only when it appears that the voluntary system of recall is not working-the State and Territory departments of health, in conjunction with the Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health, regularly monitor the situation-the Federal Minister for Consumer Affairs advises whether, and what, powers will be used to protect the public interest. To date the Minister has never had to use his power of recall. All food recalls have been done on a voluntary basis, which is commendable.

Since July 1986 there have been four national recalls involving products such as ice confection, tuna, dried food and desiccated coconut. In several States, items such as baby food, cheese, brown sugar and ricotta cheese have been recalled voluntarily during the same period. In consultation with the States and Territories, the Commonwealth has recently established the Uniform Food Law and Interpretation Committee to administer the uniform laws. At its last meeting, it recommended that some form of uniform Commonwealth recall legislation be introduced. The amendment before this House is a result of that recommendation. For instance, if the Northern Territory wanted to ban a particular product, this Committee, which has representatives of every State and Territory department of health, would consider and make recommendations to the Minister for a national recall. Two observers from New Zealand also attend these meetings in order to harmonise food laws across the Tasman.

What will happen in the future is that the national recall system will be coordinated by the Uniform Food Law and Interpretation Committee secretariat and, naturally, will be oversighted by the Committee. In order that this system of national food and beverage recall works effectively, it is imperative that the Trade Practices Act have the power to effect such recalls.

The amendments before the House have been seen by the Business Regulation Review Unit, which is set up to examine all proposals which may impose new regulations on business, and have been given the all clear. None of the amendments imposes any additional regulation. These amendments are a perfect example of administrative housekeeping by the Federal Government and demonstrate, as I have said, our concern for consumer protection. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not propose to discuss at length the machinery provisions of the Trade Practices Amendment Bill, which have been so well dealt with by previous spokesmen for the Government, including, most recently, by the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon). But let me just say two things about them. Firstly, they show the careful process of attention to the trade practices area that the Government has been following for a number of years. Trade practices legislation has become the cornerstone of consumer protection. The provisions in the Trade Practices Act form the basis of a secure understanding by consumers that they have certain rights that they can enforce in law throughout Australia. Without that broad national framework, we would go a long way backwards in protecting consumers.

SPEECH.PARA: It is particularly important to note the extension and preservation of the food product provisions in the Trade Practices Act, which, it was originally thought, would be areas adopted by the States. Because of the failure of the States to take up that challenge, it has become essential that the Commonwealth proceed to maintain the provisions in its own legislation and to provide for a national scheme of recall and food standards, which is so important. The rest of the Bill essentially contains tidying up provisions.

Let me say some things about the generality of this debate. There are issues that ought to be drawn to the attention of the public very widely. We heard from the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) a claim that the Liberal Opposition is as committed to consumer protection as the Government. That is a very easy thing to say. I would like to see a copy of the Liberal Party's policy on consumer affairs. I certainly have not been able to find one. It may be such a popular document that it is out of print, but I suspect that the reality is that no such document exists.

In this debate the Government is addressing a series of specific, concrete issues. The Opposition is responding in generalities, with no concrete policy framework in place. That is very sad. It is sad for consumers and it is sad for the political process. This process of debate and discussion should be about the contest of ideas, about two sets of policy prescriptions matched up so that the public can say, `We prefer that world view' or, `We prefer another way of seeing the situation'. Unfortunately, only one side in this debate has put forward prescriptions that can be tested and measured.

If one wants to look at where the Liberals perform in consumer affairs, where better to look than the one State which has had a Liberal administration for a considerable period. I refer to Tasmania, my home State, and a very pleasant State. One thing it does not have is any effective consumer affairs protection whatsoever at a State level. The Australian Consumers Association recently produced a document called Consuming Interest, a three-monthly newsletter. Consuming Interest has conducted a survey and made its assessment of the effectiveness of consumer affairs Ministers throughout Australia. It is interesting to note that in that assessment the Tasmanian Minister for Consumer Affairs, Mr John Beswick, is rated eighth out of nine Australian consumer affairs Ministers in terms of effectiveness. From my knowledge of Tasmanian consumer affairs, which is basic because, apart from the sale of goods Acts and one or two pieces of minor poisons legislation there is no Tasmanian consumer affairs legislation. My knowledge suggests that whoever came in ninth out of nine must represent the bottom of the bucket.

To indicate the impact that the Tasmanian Minister made in consumer affairs it is worth noting as an aside that Consuming Interest even got his name wrong. He was referred to as Richard Beswick, in the same way, I suppose, as John Fraser made an impact on the Americans when he descended to impart his wisdom to the United States. So, too, Richard John Beswick obviously has made very little impact in terms of his capacity to stamp his mark on Australian consumer affairs. That is the situation with the Liberals in the State they govern. In the State they govern there is no consumer legislation, no mechanism to protect the interests of those who are ripped off, no system to look after those who are weak and unable effectively to bargain strongly in the marketplace.

We have the platitude that the Liberals are as concerned as the Labor Party. They may be as concerned but they do nothing about it. They put no mechanisms in place. They have no national policy. At the State level in the State they administer they have enacted no laws, despite their having been in government for many years. That is a very strange claim, therefore, to make, is it not? It is a claim that cannot be supported.

Before I close my remarks, I want to say something about regulation. Of recent times a perception has been growing in the community that regulation is bad per se. That cannot be true. We regulate our affairs by laws, procedures, to ensure that we conduct ourselves safely and with care for others. Without some framework of safety and health regulations we would live in a very brutish and unsatisfactory society indeed. At a very simple level, we have traffic laws that ensure that people do not drive on both sides of the road, so that they respect each other's rights to use the roads. We insist that people driving in one direction use one side of the road and others driving in another direction drive on the opposite side. That is obvious and very straightforward. We do it to protect the public good.

In the same way, there are many areas in the consumer field where regulation is appropriate and must be implemented. It is not only in consumer fields; it is in areas where health and safety standards in the work place are important. Too simplistic analyses are sometimes made about the cost of consumer protection and regulations. Certainly, it is the case that we need to make sure that we do not have unnecessary regulation. The Government has moved by way of establishing the Business Regulation Review Unit to ensure that unnecessary regulations that impose greater burdens than benefits are cast away. But let us not throw out the baby with the bath water. There is a legitimate case for pointing out the social benefits that accrue with some processes of regulatory frameworks.

Take the very simple example of the asbestos industry. It is notoriously difficult for individual litigants to prove damage as a result of exposure to asbestos. Cases are before the courts at this very time in which the plaintiffs have been seeking damages. They claim that they have been injured by exposure to asbestos at the work place and as a consequence have suffered a diminution in their life span, that they have had various effects in their lungs. Some instances of that kind have been before the courts for years. Unfortunately, those claims are vigorously defended.

I understand that at present only one such case has proceeded to a successful conclusion and that obstacles for plaintiffs in such cases are manifold. For example, there may be alternative exposures other than at the work place. There may be instances where people have smoked and therefore some of the symptoms in their lungs might be attributable equally to the smoking as to the asbestos. So there is this long, protracted situation in which those who have been exposed to harm have found it enormously difficult to battle individual cases through the courts. The upshot is that almost everyone who is familiar with this area believe that many people whose health and life spans have been significantly reduced by the asbestos industry will never be able to claim compensation from that industry.

My experience with such claims arises out of the Baryugil litigation. For some short time I was associated with claims being pursued by a community of Aboriginal workers who had claimed that they had been affected by asbestos exposure in the north of New South Wales. It is a very sad case. It had been given the attention of the Houses of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal affairs and the Caucus Aboriginal affairs committees in years past. That case has been pursued in the civil courts over many years. The length of that protracted case seems to be an instance in which the long, slow process of individuals seeking redress is not an appropriate or effective mechanism.

Instead of just saying that we will leave this to the market, we need to set up some form of health and safety controls to make sure that mining is conducted in a safe and non-hazardous way. Although those controls impose certain cost burdens on the industry, the cost to us as a society is minimised because the controls avoid the personal tragedies of the people who have been exposed and also reduce the health costs and the various social costs that go with looking after people whose health has been affected.

So there are always two sides of the regulatory equation. On the one side we must weight up the costs to a particular institution or industry and on the other we have the cost to the community of not regulating, and having to pick up substantial costs spread over a number of years-health costs, social costs and costs that are involved with coping with the effect of an unregulated work force, unsafe products or contaminated food. It is important to realise in weighing up our response in the overall framework of regulation that it is not a one-way street, that it is not simply an imposition of costs on industry but also a measure that is designed to ensure that the impact on society of the costs of an unregulated industry which it would otherwise impose is reduced. Where those costs are too extreme and where health and welfare risks are so high as to be unacceptable they should be eliminated. We are slowly realising with products such as asbestos that the risks of using them effectively means that their use has to be eliminated.

All I wish to say in conclusion is that there is a real challenge in terms of our thinking in this debate for us to focus on regulation not only as a cost to service providers but also as a benefit to the community as a whole to make sure that we do not pick up in the future all the additional social costs. The Government has put in place a very balanced framework. It is conscious of the need to continue a strong front on consumer affairs. Its legislation is in place and its record is one of which it can be proud. The consumer affairs provisions of the Trade Practices Act are a very important element. The amendments proposed in the Bill will streamline the provisions of the Act and make them work more effectively. By contrast, the Opposition has no claim in justice to say that it has any concern in this area. It has no policy and in the State in which it holds government it has taken no action in this area. So the contrast should be clear to those who are concerned to ensure that the health and the interests of consumers throughout Australia are safeguarded. The message should be clear to those who wish to make a judgment between the respective claims of the two sides that have put arguments before this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has this got to do with 65u?

TALK.START.PARA: —Section 65u of the Trade Practices Act relates to food recall. It is worth while bringing to the attention of the Committee the fact that food, of all consumer goods, is the most important because of its impact on people's health. The food industry in Australia is very competitive and essentially it is a very efficient industry. In my brief time as Minister for Consumer Affairs I had the opportunity to get closely involved with the industry and, I believe, to develop a very good relationship with it. The competitive and very sophisticated food industry is very much aware of the problems that can be caused to a particular manufacturer in the industry or, through spin-offs, to other manufacturers producing similar products if a product produced by one manufacturer proves in some way or another to be defective and worthy of recall. That is why the food industry takes this issue very seriously.

SPEECH.PARA: In the time I was Minister for Consumer Affairs there were few examples of this type of problem and they were handled most efficiently. Unfortunately, there have been instances in the past, despite the fact that there has been no need for mandatory recall, where the procedures have not gone smoothly. Part of the problem is that we are dealing with an issue in which the manufacturers as well as the distributors are involved. Once food leaves the factory and moves through the distributors and retail outlets into the homes of consumers the distribution process is far more diffuse and the difficulty of retrieving unsafe food becomes far more difficult. Because of the relationship of food to health, safety, and so on, it has a great impact on the consumer and, in effect, on the retailer, or more particularly on the manufacturer. The food industry is very concerned about this, as well it may be, and I appreciate the work it has done in ensuring that the processes work well.

In talking about food standards and food as a consumer item it is worth while going back about 85 years to when we as a Commonwealth started talking about food standards, model food Acts and related issues. For 85 years, in one way or another, we have been trying to get some form of uniformity in Australia in food standards and matters such as we are dealing with in section 65u. It has taken us that long. Why should we be wanting to extend for another two years, as has been suggested by the Opposition, the time for the States to introduce uniform food standards. I know that the sun has been going down on the Liberal and National parties for a long time but I did not think they liked sunsets so much that they should want to bring in another one through this amendment. I appreciate the acceptance by the Opposition of the spirit and the letter of two of the amendments proposed by the Trade Practices Amendment Bill. I also accept the spirit of the Opposition amendment seeking to extend the sunset provision. But let us face it; there is quite a difference between the spirit and the letter of this amendment.

Section 65u was inserted into the Act in 1986 at the insistence of Senator Haines in the Senate. Her intentions were good. Basically she said that it was to give the industry time in which to pressure the States into introducing consumer protection legislation in the area of food and drink supply and sale which was uniform and incorporated all the requirements contained in the Federal trade practices legislation.

That intention, quite simply, has not been realised and nor is it likely to be in the foreseeable future. Of all the requirements in part V, division 1a, of the Act, only the mandatory recall of goods has been proposed for adoption by the State and Territory authorities, and only two jurisdictions-Queensland and Western Australia-have in fact made the necessary regulations. As honourable members would realise, there is quite a difference between bringing in the Act and promulgating the regulations that in this case would require the recall of food. Even so, that has not been done in a uniform manner. The honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) commented on that. I have no problem accepting his comments; I think that that should have been done. The States have had plenty of opportunity to introduce legislation but they have not, and certainly not in a uniform manner.

That is one of the things raised by many members on both sides in relation to the transport of food across State boundaries. That is one of the problems we have. The food industry, of all industries in Australia, is a national-based industry. It is not related to just one State; it is a national industry and an international industry, and that needs to be considered. The presence of a Commonwealth Act of mandatory recall provisions is in any case desirable to ensure that hazardous goods banned in one jurisdiction are not dumped in another and can be withdrawn from sale simultaneously throughout Australia. Costs to the industry are also minimised when compared with the costs of complying with various State and Territory provisions. If the honourable member for Ryan, as I am sure he does from time to time, talks to people in the food industry he would know that one of the biggest problems that the industry has, whether in relation to packaging, labelling or whatever, is having to comply with the various regulations from State to State instead of being able to deal with a national approach. That is what it wants and that is what we are suggesting here. That will give it security. If this provision were not enacted costs to the industry could possibly increase. The other point that needs to be noted, because the Government is concerned about efficient industry and costs to industry, for the benefit of the industry, exporters and the consumer, is that this amendment will not impose any further regulation upon the food and drink industry as appropriate regulation currently exists. I believe the industry is quite happy with what exists.

We have heard a lot of talk about States rights in relation to section 65u but we have not heard much about the things that go with such rights, that is, responsibilities. We have been talking about this whole general area for 85 years. I see no point in extending if for another two, another two after that and another two after that. That is the way it would go. I appreciate the Opposition's acceptance of the Government's Bill and the principles it has espoused but the Government cannot accept the proposal to extend it for a further sunset period of two years. If the States have not taken it up now there would be no incentivation, if you like, for them to take it up within another two years. It is a bit like Old Man River-it just keeps rolling along. People will realise the potential danger of any uncoordinated acts of recall. This legislation does give a national approach. It gives protection to the consumer, it gives protection to industry and I believe it gives protection to good government. For that reason I am afraid the Government will have to reject the amendment put forward by the Opposition.
Amendment negatived.
Bill agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition fully supports the Norfolk Island Amendment Bill 1988, which will enable a further increase to this Territory's self-government powers. This legislation amends the Norfolk Island Act of 1979 to enable the Norfolk Island Government to appoint its own auditor to audit the public accounts of the Territory. While this Bill refers specifically to Norfolk Island, the Opposition is pleased to see legislation being brought before the House which enables our other Territories to have a greater sense of independence.

SPEECH.PARA: The Norfolk Island Administration has proved to be very effective and efficient. I understand that there is a lesson to be learned by governments of a larger nature as far as budget deficits are concerned. Norfolk Island has had very few. In fact, some of its annual funding is received, to the extent of $300,000, from interest on its investments. That would indicate that its foreign debt is probably not as great as ours, nor is its government debt. This is the case even though we might call it a tax haven, as I understand that the maximum tax imposed on the inhabitants is a $200 a year works levy. So all in all I think this particular Administration can give a lesson to its mainland cousins. Therefore, it makes sense that it be given greater powers over its own affairs, as suggested by this Bill.

The amendment itself is a Norfolk Island initiative, and obviously it would be quite happy to see the Bill passed. Under the Norfolk Island Act 1979 the accounts of the Territory were subject to inspection and audit by the Auditor-General of the Commonwealth. This amendment will enable the Norfolk Island Administration, on advice from the Norfolk Island Legislative Assembly, to appoint its own auditor, whether it be a firm or an individual, and to determine the auditor's terms and conditions of employment. However, this does not prevent the Norfolk Island Administration from appointing as its audi-tor the Auditor-General, and of course the Auditor-General may accept that appointment. The Bill ensures that the person or firm appointed as auditor must be registered as an auditor under the Companies Act 1981 of the Commonwealth or the Companies Act 1985 of the Territory. The Territory's accounts must be audited at least once a year and the auditor must provide the President and the Administrator with a report on the inspection and audit. The definition of `accounts of the Territory' is:
the accounts and records of financial transactions of the Administration and records relating to assets of, or in the custody of, the Administration;

Provision is made for the Legislative Assembly to set auditing standards to be complied with by the audit and for the auditor's report to be tabled in the Legislative Assembly and sent to the Minister. The proposed amendments have no direct financial implication. As shown in the legislation, suitable safeguards are built into the amendments. While the Bill may seem a minor one, it is an important step towards the Norfolk Island Administration gaining greater responsibility and independence in the long term.

I would like also to deal with the position of some of the other assemblies of our Territories. In particular, the Northern Territory has a problem. Even though it is self-governing, it lacks residual powers in certain respects. I understand residual powers could be passed to it, almost in the same way as these audit powers are being passed to Norfolk Island, that would enable the Territory itself to become economically independent, as this Government would want it to be, by way of making funding available to it on the basis that it is in effect a State. This economic independence would mean that it would have to have power over certain areas within its own jurisdiction. For instance, in relation to uranium residual powers have not yet been transferred to the Northern Territory Government and yet uranium mining must be seen as one aspect of the growth of the Northern Territory economy. Also, Kakadu National Park and other parks in the Territory are still under the control of the Federal Government in Canberra. Powers over the parks have not been transferred. Similarly, the land rights question is firmly in the hands of the Government and not the Territory, although the Territory Government would like to have such power. That is also the case with the other two areas I have mentioned. Transferring further residual powers in order to provide better government in the Territory would be more than appreciated.

The other matter is one of industrial affairs, not a major one I believe, but one that should be considered also in that transfer arrangement. I also point out to the Norfolk Island Assembly the dangers that it faces being an assembly under the direct control of the Federal Government. In September of last year, the Christmas Island Assembly, only two weeks after re-election, was discharged from its responsibilities. That is putting it mildly; perhaps I should say that it was sacked by this Government. All control was taken from it despite the fact that it had been encouraged to hold that election only two weeks earlier.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't believe in democracy.

—The Government does not believe in democracy, unless it operates in the way it defines it. If that can happen to the Christmas Island Assembly, I suggest that for one reason or another it could happen to any of the other assemblies in the Territories. I suggest that the assemblies in the Territories and Norfolk Island proceed cautiously with this as a reminder as there are still jurisdictional problems.

SPEECH.PARA: I mentioned earlier that the task of the auditor is to examine records relating to the assets of Norfolk Island. The assets of great significance at the moment are the artefacts from the historic shipwreck, HMS Sirius. Whilst I know that the Minister at the table, the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch) has given certain reassurances, there are problems, so I think it would be worth while reiterating them, particularly in our bicentennial year. There was an article in the Age of 2 February by Mr Kevin Childs, which brought attention to the problems faced in this regard. I think it is important to give a bit of the background of the shipwreck as it is probably one of the most significant assets owned by the Norfolk Island Assembly.

What probably is not recognised in this bicentennial year is that HMS Sirius, which was one of the ships in the original fleet-we witnessed the re-enactment of its arrival on Australia Day 1988-was shipwrecked on Norfolk Island in 1790. The wreck remained untouched for quite a while, although it was known to be there. It was thought to be too dangerous to take too much off the ship, but certain provisions and artefacts were taken off at the time of the actual shipwreck. As I say, the wreck has great significance. People tend to believe that the Sirius is a wholly Australian-owned possession, being shipwrecked in our waters, although I understand that it would be debatable as to whether it was shipwrecked in Australian waters. I have not had the benefit of visiting Norfolk Island. I might suggest to the Minister that, if I am to discharge my duties properly, a visit to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, Christmas Island and Norfolk Island, should be well within the order of things of this Government. Anyone who wants to visit Norfolk Island has to have his or her passport stamped with a visa before entering and leaving.

One must question whether HMS Sirius was shipwrecked in Australian waters. The Norfolk Islanders certainly have much pride in this. The dispute centres around the fact that the Australian Bicentennial Authority-I cannot give the date-bought into this matter by funding three expeditions to the Sirius wreck. These were headed by Mr Graeme Henderson, who I believe is the curator of the Western Australian Maritime Museum. There was a preliminary expedition in December 1983 under Graeme Henderson. There was a full expedition in February-March 1985, and then a further full expedition in January-February 1987. Because the Australian Bicentennial Authority did buy into that as far as funding was concerned, probably with the assistance of the Western Australian Maritime Museum, there was some expectation that as a result the artefacts recovered belonged to the Australian Bicentennial Authority or perhaps the Australian Government and did not lie within the possession of Norfolk Island. The significance of the find can be assessed from the following comments that Mr Henderson made, which were widely quoted at the time:
These artefacts throw new light on the flag ship of the First Fleet.
Historically the Sirius can be described as Australia's most significant shipwreck but it has long been considered archaeologically barren. Now it has been revealed as a rich archaeological site.
We are gathering a collection of great national importance and it is evident that there is a wealth of more material on the site.

In fact some 600 artefacts were recovered at that time and there are indications that a significant number remain on the site. An initial agreement was then entered into between the Norfolk Island Government and the Australian Bicentennial Authority to allow some of these artefacts to be loaned to the travelling exhibition that is going around Australia at the moment. There is also an arrangement for conservation treatment to be given to the artefacts in Western Australia. Subsequent to all of that a loan was agreed to by the Norfolk Island Government to the 1988 Australian Bicentennial Exhibition, the travelling exhibition, and they also agreed in principle for the Government to loan specified relics to the International Cultural Corporation of Australia Ltd.

The Norfolk Island Government perceived distinct changes in this attitude by the various mainland agencies and the rather extreme comments as to its right of possession, custody and control of the Sirius's relics. However, there was an assurance given by the former Minister for Territories, the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen), having been written to by the Administrator and by the Government, that the assets did belong to the Norfolk Island Government. But again the stress was there to make these relics and other things available for viewing on the mainland. In that respect we do have an assurance. I will later deal with the fact that the Minister has given a further assurance, which is welcomed, but perhaps I can explain later on that it is felt to be qualified, and there may be reasons for that. An assurance was given in 1984 by the Minister at the time that the relics were in fact Norfolk Island assets.

The 1983 expedition report suggested that a Sirius museum should be established on the island to bring together as far as possible all material which was in the hands of some private collectors and also on the mainland. There, with appropriate stories and displays, the link between the history of the Island and the First Fleet could be on show. The 1985 expedition report also proceeded on the assumption that Norfolk Island would be the home of the Sirius collection, and this assumption was, of course, based on the Minister's assurance. Everything was going okay until then. The bicentennial loans then developed a character of their own. The Bicentennial Authority and the International Cultural Corporation of Australia seemed to be insisting on that greatest of all things that one can get from the Government, a non-repayable grant. Having received agreement from Norfolk Island to the loan of certain artefacts, agreement on a more permanent basis was sought in the form of an extended loan to both authorities.

On 22 October 1987 at a Senate Estimates committee hearing in Canberra, Senator Richardson was asked by Senator Puplick about the status of the wreck Sirius and about who should have control of the artefacts that were disco-vered as a result of the work carried out on the wreck. The pertinent part of Senator Richardson's reply was that, given that the vessel went down in 1790, it presumably comes within the definition of a declared shipwreck. Senator Richardson said further:
We are in the process, as you may know, of establishing a national maritime museum in Darling Harbour which would be able to present the artefacts from the Sirius in an appropriate location.

People who live in Sydney and are close to the centre of power offer the argument that those artefacts would then be viewed by the greatest number of people. Others may have sympathy for that argument, but I suggest that Sydney would not be the best place to exhibit such artefacts. I refer not only to these particular items but also to other maritime artefacts that have been discovered around the Australian coastline. It may be that four million Sydney-siders would find that remark argumentative, but I believe there are other places of greater stature than Sydney. Obviously the residents of Norfolk Island believe that these historic artefacts could provide the base for a tourist industry at a resting place within view of where the Sirius went down and within a short distance of the pier itself.

Senator Richardson then passed the matter over to a Mr Sergi. I understand Mr Sergi was the secretary to a Minister in the Federal Labor Government and that he transferred to the Australian National Maritime Museum. Mr Sergi suggested that by the artefacts being placed in Sydney the objects could be preserved in a professional way. This suggests that there is no professionalism on Norfolk Island to maintain the artefacts. I became interested in this matter when the name Sergi was first mentioned. In relation to the Pine Island lighthouse off Mackay, which has a 100-year history in the area, the Government made a concerted effort, through the Minister of the day and the Australian National Maritime Museum in Sydney, to take the Pine Island lighthouse from the Barrier Reef and place it in the middle of Sydney on the reasoning that more people could view it there. I could not think of anything more out of character than a lighthouse in the middle of the Darling Harbour complex or at the maritime museum. The lighthouse belongs on the Barrier Reef.

In this regard I congratulate the former Minister, the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren), on his efforts. He gave an undertaking that the Pine Island lighthouse would remain on the coastline at Mackay and that it would not be transferred to Sydney. However, in spite of that assurance there is lingering doubt about what will happen. The mechanisms and lenses associated with the lighthouse are subject to a loan-this famous old method of transfer of possession-which has to be renewed every 12 months. I can see some reason for that but while ever they are subject to a loan to the Mackay lighthouse museum doubts remain as to whether they will always be in that position. Since that time, another lighthouse was taken away by stealth from the Cape Bowling Green area. The lighthouse was unmanned and was dismantled without any notification being given to me as the local member. That lighthouse was used to replace the Pine Island lighthouse in the museum.

The then Minister, the honourable member for Robertson, said the artefact would remain the asset of the Norfolk Island Government. However, things have changed. The statement of Senator Richardson and the comments of Mr Sergi suggest that there was a determination to have those assets transferred from Norfolk Island to Sydney. Things got to such a state that the government of Norfolk Island refused to contemplate a fourth expedition to raise further artefacts because it was not reassured of the continuation of the commitment by the Minister in 1984 that the artefacts would remain on and in possession of the island. As my officers have indicated to you, I am prepared to reaffirm Mr Cohen's assurances, subject to the provisions of the Historic Shipwrecks Act . . . Norfolk Island will be the home of the `Sirius' relics, it needs to be resolved how this can be realised under the Act.
There was, therefore, a slight qualification. Later in that letter he removed that qualification to a large extent. He said:
I have no reservations in confirming that, subject to the Act, custody of the relics will be with the Norfolk Island Government.

He said that the Sirius had significance for the 16 million mainland residents as well as the residents of Norfolk Island. The following qualification appears in the final paragraph on the first page of the Minister's letter:
