SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that the Opposition has chosen to support the Norfolk Island Amendment Bill. Obviously it is non-controversial. As the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) has just indicated, it proposes to appoint an auditor to look after the affairs of the Norfolk Island Government and, therefore, to remove the responsibility of the Commonwealth's Auditor-General for that particular task.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Dawson raised a number of points not only in connection with this Bill but also in respect of issues generally within the portfolio of the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch), who is at the table. I am sure that he will respond to a number of those points. Therefore, I will decline from making any comment myself. I would like to refer principally to the Bill itself and to the whole question of Norfolk Island self-government proposals. I think it is important that we look at the historical context in which we are examining the Bill before us today so that we do have a full appreciation of some of the difficulties which are obviously experienced in an outpost such as Norfolk Island not only by the Legislative Assembly but also by the Commonwealth Government in administering that particular area.

The Norfolk Island Act 1913 declared that Norfolk Island be accepted by the Commonwealth as a Territory. In its historic context there is a deal of common ground between the Territory and Australia. It was governed by the Commonwealth initially under the provisions of that Act and subsequently under the provisions of the Norfolk Island Act 1957. Until the advent of the Whitlam Government, however, Norfolk Island was the victim of chance legislation and attitudes, but had very little interest taken in it. I think that is a sad reflection on what I understand to be a particularly beautiful area off the coast of Australia. I think it says something about a range of governments, up until the Whitlam Government in 1972-75, that that lack of interest dominated. The Minister for the Capital Territory in the Whitlam Government, Kep Enderby, visited Norfolk Island and demonstrated an interest in it in the early days of that Government. As a result, the Whitlam Government was very much aware that Norfolk Island was a fragile community economically, socially and environmentally and that in some way the Government, therefore, had to have a greater responsibility for its maintenance.

In an attempt to find solutions to this situation, in 1975 the Whitlam Government gave Sir John Nimmo a royal commission to recommend on the future status of Norfolk Island and its constitutional relationship with Australia and on other associated matters. The report of the Royal Commission into Matters Relating to Norfolk Island containing 74 recommendations was presented to the Fraser Government in October 1976. In November 1978, some two years later, the Minister for Home Affairs, Bob Ellicott, presented the Norfolk Island Bill 1978 to the House on the basis that the Fraser Government `recognised the special relationship of the . . . descendants of Norfolk Island and their desire to preserve their traditions and culture . . . and considered it to be desirable and to be the wish of the people that Norfolk Island achieved, over a period of time, internal self-government as a Territory under the authority of the Commonwealth'. Indeed, these sentiments are shared equally on this side of the House. It does concern me though that once the Royal Commission report was tabled it took two years for the legislation on this matter to come forward. Indeed, it was some additional time before anything further was done on it.

It should be noted that whilst the Minister in presenting the legislation admitted in his second reading speech that in drafting this legislation the government of the day-that is, the Fraser Government-had departed from the Royal Commission report's recommendations in certain respects, it would be fair to say that the political interests of the Fraser Government rivalled the interests of Norfolk Islanders for priority in the legislation.

When the second reading debate resumed in April 1979, the Australian Labor Party made clear its position on the legislation and on this issue of self-government for Norfolk Island. It fully supported self-government for Norfolk Island. It opposed the legislation because it believed it did not give self-government, in the true and complete sense, to the island. The Labor Party claimed that the legislation failed to accommodate fully the wishes of the islanders in regard to their future mode of government. Consequently, the Labor Party proposed amendments to the Bill which provided for a greater control over machinery matters of government for the proposed Norfolk Island Legislative Assembly. It proposed a number of other measures. These included control over a much wider number of matters of government; a reduction in the Australian Government's powers in the Bill; the provision of social security and an industrial court for Norfolk Island; the extension of Australian taxation legislation to Norfolk Island; a Bill of Rights to be included in the Bill; and the proposed Norfolk Island Legislative Assembly to be elected by the method of proportional representation.

It is sad to report that the amendments proposed by the opposition of the day-the Labor Party-were defeated along party lines. However, the resulting Norfolk Island Act 1979 foreshadowed that within a five-year period consideration would be given to extending the powers conferred on the Legislative Assembly and other political and administrative institutions. Fortunately for Norfolk Island, the Labor Party was again elected to office in that five-year period. The Hawke Labor Government, not surprisingly, fully endorsed the principle of transferring more functions and responsibility to Norfolk Island in an effort to promote an increase in the degree of self-government. After appropriate consultation and negotiation, which of course is the hallmark of the Hawke Government, the following additional powers have been transferred to the Legislative Assembly: Public Service of the Territory; public works; lotteries, betting and gaming; civil defence and emergency services; Territory archives; and matters incidental to, or consequential on, the execution of Executive authority.
We now have before the House the Norfolk Island Amendment Bill 1988, which proposes to allow for Norfolk Island to appoint its own auditor-yet another step towards total self-government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very respectable people.

—I agree with my colleague the honourable member for Dawson and his comments about auditors in general. He has suggested that reputable firms and so on will perhaps be approached in order to occupy this position, which is again in keeping with this Government's approach to the appointment of auditors of this nature.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal is, therefore, entirely appropriate in respect of the appointment of an independent Auditor-General. The moneys involved belong to Norfolk Island. I think that needs to be pointed out at the outset. They are collected through customs duties and the sale of stamps, et cetera, and are used to provide services such as roads, schools and civil defence to residents on the island. It could be argued that the moneys are not Commonwealth moneys as such. What interest does the Commonwealth Auditor-General have in Norfolk Island moneys? It is an argument which I suppose could be debated at length; nevertheless, I think it is an appropriate one, given the commitment that this Government has to self-government of that island. The Norfolk Island Minister for Finance has posed this question with respect to what interest the Commonwealth Auditor-General has in Norfolk Island moneys, and has proposed that the island should have the power to appoint its own auditor. The Auditor-General, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) have agreed, provided that certain safeguards are applied. Therefore, the legislation has come forward. It is yet another example of this Government's and the Labor Party's commitment to self-government for Norfolk Island.

As I have indicated, and as the honourable member for Dawson indicated in his speech, this is not a controversial piece of legislation. It adds further to the autonomy that is so necessary for Territories such as Norfolk Island. It is an appropriate piece of legislation for the times. I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The Government welcomes the support of the Opposition for the Norfolk Island Amendment Bill 1988. This Bill enables me to touch on a number of issues, some of which the shadow Minister has raised. I am sure that there is a good deal of bipartisan support for a substantial number of those issues. I take this opportunity to say that, with a couple of notable exceptions, such as Christmas Island, there is a fair deal of bipartisan support between us on external territories matters. Given the nature of external territories, that is a good thing.

SPEECH.PARA: The first matter I mention to the House concerns the sewerage scheme. The Commonwealth has agreed to contribute $2m to the cost of a new sewerage scheme on Norfolk Island. We think that this will reduce the risk to health on the island and any potential danger to the tourist industry which, of course, is the mainstay of the island's economy. In regard to the Kingston and Arthurs Vale historic area, the Commonwealth has contributed $4.5m to the restoration of the historic buildings in the area. These buildings represent one of the finest collections of colonial buildings in the Commonwealth. They are listed in the Register of the National Estate and they are some of the major tourist attractions on the island.

Norfolk Island has benefited quite significantly from various bicentennial programs on the island, to the tune of $416,700. From this amount $284,000 has been allocated for an interpretive plan, including the establishment of a visitors information centre. The amount also includes a local government initiative grants schemes and money for the local and regional heritage program. An amount of $120,000 has been allocated for conservation work on the All Saints Church and $6,000 for a sport and recreation program. An environmental program around Bucks Point-a scenic walking trail-has been allocated $2,900. That total of $416,700 includes some other matters which I did not spell out. There is an ongoing commitment by this Government concerning the transfer of powers to the Norfolk Island Government. Since the Norfolk Island Act was passed in 1979 the powers of the Norfolk Island Government have been extended. TALK.START.PARA: —Citizenship?

—I will come to that. In regard to employment, the Commonwealth has been assisting the Norfolk Island Government in the development of employment legislation for the island. At present there is none. A Bill has been passed by the local Assembly which will provide for workers compensation, minimum wages and conditions, machinery for conciliation and adjudicating disputes, and safe working practices. That will require our consideration as well.

SPEECH.PARA: One matter that I should turn to for a few moments relates to the Sirius wreck and the relics. There has been some disquiet about this matter in the past. The Sirius is an important issue to the people of Norfolk Island. I am also pleased to report to the House that the Commonwealth is at what we consider to be an advanced stage of negotiations with the Norfolk Island Government about the arrangements for disposition, conservation and display of those relics from the Sirius which, as the honourable member for Dawson quite rightly pointed out, was the flagship of the First Fleet. Norfolk Island will be the home of the relics but, according to the Commonwealth, the mainland will need to have access to those relics from time to time. We think that that is very important.

The honourable member asked why some matters were still outstanding. I thank him for the opportunity in this debate to talk for a few moments about that. Essentially there are two very important points. Having reaffirmed that Norfolk Island will be the home of those relics it has to be said also that because this ship was the flagship of the First Fleet there should be access to the relics from time to time-they are of very great historical and cultural import to this country-for the other 16 million Australians. Whilst Norfolk Island will be the home of the relics, other Australians need to have access to them from time to time. That is one of the central points of negotiations that are going on at the moment. We believe that the negotiations will be completed with a mutually satisfactory outcome.

The second and, I think, most important point in this regard is that under the Historic Shipwrecks Act, I, as the relevant Minister, have a duty to see to the conservation, preservation and display of the Sirius relics and other relics of that import. When we discuss with the Norfolk Island Government-as we are-the need for access by Australians on the mainland to some of the relics from time to time, we need to be satisfied that the conservation and preservation of those relics will be done, and done properly. We are really doing no more than undertaking the obligation bestowed on us as a government and, in particular, myself as the Minister, under the Historic Shipwrecks Act. In that light, since I have pointed this out through my officers in clearer terms, the Norfolk Island Government is seeing the necessity of our position as well.

They are two very important points. I say to the honourable member for Dawson that they are important. They are obligations as opposed to predispositions. We are now quite convinced that there will be a mutually satisfactory outcome, as I said earlier, in these negotiations between the Commonwealth and the Norfolk Island Government. I say to the shadow Minister that I will be going to Norfolk Island early next month to talk to the Norfolk Island Government, the Administrator and, more generally, the people about a range of issues on Norfolk Island, but in particular about the Sirius relics. I know, as the honourable member has pointed out, how important the issue is to many people on Norfolk Island. It remains only for me to again recommend the Bill to the House. I thank the Opposition for its support. The provision for the Norfolk Island Government to appoint its own auditor to carry out the auditing of the island's public accounts is an important milestone for the people of Norfolk Island and an important contribution by this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill proposes amendments to the National Crime Authority Act and the Telecommunications (Interception) Act. I intend to confine my opening remarks to the amendments proposed to the National Crime Authority Act. At the outset let me say that the National Crime Authority (NCA) has the full and wholehearted support of the coalition parties. Accordingly, we support the principal amendment, which is to repeal the five-year sunset clause so as to place the NCA on a permanent footing. To put my remarks in context, it would be useful to retrace the origins and development of the NCA. The initiative for the establishment of a permanent national law enforcement agency in Australia came from the coalition parties. It dates back to the Fraser Government and was reflected in the National Crimes Commission Act 1982. That Act was passed when the Fraser Government was in office but was not implemented by the Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: In the late 1970s and the early 1980s, Australia was faced with ever-growing signs that traditional methods of law enforcement, based on police forces and occasional royal commissions, could not cope adequately with the increasing sophistication of organised crime and drug trafficking with worldwide tentacles. That position was clearly identified in the reports of three royal commissioners-Mr Justice Williams in 1980, Mr Costigan in 1982 and Mr Justice Stewart in 1983. I quote briefly from a report delivered in 1983 by Mr Justice Stewart:

A crimes commission that is continuously looking for patterns of action and association is far more likely to identify crime as organised crime than is the ordinary law enforcement agency. A national crime commission has the opportunity of monitoring activities which take place anywhere in Australia.

In the Williams National Crimes Commission in 1980 it was said that criminal law in Australia is ill equipped to deal with any organised basis for illegal activities. That was the rationale behind the National Crime Authority Act. In the early 1980s the then Attorney-General, Senator Peter Durack, undertook an extensive study of international law enforcement methodologies. To this end Senator Durack had consultations with top law enforcement officials in the United States of America and the United Kingdom. In addition, a study was made of initiatives taken in Hong Kong and other places. Last but not least, Senator Durack initiated a series of consultations with the States at ministerial and senior officer level in the hope of achieving national agreement on an appropriate body with the necessary expertise and powers to make an effective attack on organised crime. That was a good example of the cooperative, federalist approach adopted by the last Fraser Government, which is unfortunately in some instances in marked contrast to the confrontationist approach adopted by this Labor Government in some areas of policy.

The end product of the activity to which I have referred was the National Crimes Commission Bill, which passed through the Parliament at the end of 1982. History shows that the Commission had not been established by the time of the 1983 Federal election. It is a matter of public knowledge that the incoming Labor Government, though accepting the need for a new vehicle to fight organised crime, did not fully embrace the concept of a national crimes commission. The main voice of dissent appeared to favour a standing or permanent royal commission. The proponents of this view pointed to the apparent successes of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, and other royal commissions. The Government put the issue to a summit by convening the National Crimes Commission Conference in the Senate chamber in July 1983 with a broad spectrum of representation including Ministers, members of parliament, royal commissioners, judges, police commissioners, and senior public servants, drawn from both the Federal and State spheres, together with other interested groups and individuals. I do not propose to canvass the debate which ensued; it is a matter of public record for all to read. Suffice it to say the conference came to the coalition's view that Australia needed a new approach to combating organised crime, generally along the lines of the National Crimes Commission. To illustrate this point further I quote in part from the Government's second reading speech in this House:

One of the most difficult policy questions with which the Government has had to wrestle is whether it is necessary or desirable for the kind of body to which Mr Costigan refers to be established with full traditional royal commission powers. After considering carefully the contrary viewpoints, the Government has taken the position, as did the Fraser Government before it with the National Crimes Commission Act 1982, that there are basic differences between the role of a royal commission and that of an ongoing Crime Authority, and that this should be reflected in the make-up of that Authority.

On 10 December 1983 this Government introduced the National Crime Authority Bill into the Senate. Shortly thereafter, on the initiative of the coalition, the Bill was referred to the Senate Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. The Committee's report, tabled on 1 May 1984, consisted of a majority report, a minority report by the late Senator Alan Missen, and to which I shall later refer, and several dissenting reports. In the event, the Government accepted 39 of the 49 recommendations of the majority report. The Fraser Government's initiative finally became reality with the passage into law of the National Crime Authority Act on 1 July 1984. When people speak about the Fraser Government and its record, and they ask me about some of the good things that the Government achieved, I point to the history of the development of the concept of the NCA. That achievement is not often heralded, but the concept was initiated by the Fraser Government and is very much to the credit of Mr Fraser and Senator Durack.

History will record that this legislation has been an important turning point in Australia's fight against organised crime. For the first time Australia has a twentieth century custom-designed organisation to combat a twentieth century problem. The NCA, combined with more recent legislation dealing with the proceeds of crime, mutual assistance, pecuniary penalties, telephone tapping powers for the States, a new Extradition Act, and later this year the Cash Transaction Reports Act, has at last armed us with an impressive array of powers and machinery to turn the tables on organised crooks. I acknowledge that finally the Government has made available this array of weapons for the law enforcement authorities. The Opposition gives credit where credit is due. However, success is not guaranteed and we must be ever vigilant to identify and to combat new and complex methods as they are developed by ingenious crime bosses. The Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority is playing a leading role in that regard; I shall return to that issue later. I also note that the State governments have a continuing role in the whole area of law enforcement. I congratulate Mr Greiner on his victory in the New South Wales election last Saturday. I am sure that a factor in the minds of many voters was Mr Greiner's determination to establish the independent commission against corruption, and that the new Attorney-General for New South Wales, Mr John Dowd, will do a good job overseeing the creation of that body. At this stage I wish to refer to the Liberal Party's policy on the NCA enunciated in the 1987 Federal election. The policy states:
The Liberal Party acknowledges the part already played by the National Crime Authority in the fight against major crime in Australia.

To ensure that the NCA can act in a manner appropriate for such an organisation, the next Liberal Government will amend the National Crime Authority Act to allow the Authority: to have stronger powers to require answers and production of documents, to operate free of political direction and veto, to extend the definition of what constitutes a `relevant criminal activity', to act on its own initiative, without requiring references from State or Federal sources, to remove the present `sunset clause' and ensure its continued operation-
a matter which is before us today-

to apply in its own right for judicial warrants for telephone interceptions . . . Every effort must be made to ensure that there is enough contact with other law enforcement agencies to ensure maximum use is made of the specialist qualities of each and that there be no duplication of effort. Because of the small number of members and the more limited scope of the NCA, this is more applicable here than with other bodies.

These are very useful proposals which have been very carefully put together by the former shadow Minister responsible for this area, my predecessor, Senator Archer. I am currently reviewing all aspects of our policy as we move to finalise policies by the second half of this year. I am certainly looking at all of these matters. Our policy will certainly contain a strong commitment to the retention of the NCA. I therefore do not foresee any major changes in this area. But I believe that it is important that we retain some flexibility in our policy so that we can be free to adopt any of the sensible recommendations which, I am sure, will emanate from the NCA's monitoring committee report.

The current Bill removes the sunset clause. On this point I note that in its 1986-87 annual report the NCA refers to the Government's election commitment and Opposition statements to the same effect to put the NCA on a permanent basis and suggests that a review of the legislation in the light of operational experience be undertaken so that proposals for changes can be considered in time for inclusion in the amending legislation. The Opposition supports this approach. Indeed, who could gainsay such a rational proposition? However, what has happened? We have the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding) bringing the Bill into this House without the benefit of a general review. Why is this so? It is simply because the Attorney-General's Department has suddenly realised that the term of the Chairman is due to expire on 30 June and that, unless quick action is taken, the NCA could find itself without a chairman and a leader.

Fortunately for the Government, the Parliamentary Joint Committee has come to the rescue by announcing, on 5 March, its intention to conduct `an evaluation of the performance of the Authority to date'. For this purpose it has called for public submissions. Not surprisingly, the Government is breathing a sigh of relief to have been let off the hook on this issue. However, the reality is that the Parliamentary Joint Committee is unlikely to report until late April or early May at the earliest. Against this timeframe it is unlikely that the Government's reaction to the Committee's report could be endorsed and legislation drafted, introduced and passed before the Parliament rises on 26 May. At best it is possible that the Committee will issue an interim report on the issues raised in the Bill.

To return to the Parliamentary Joint Statutory Committee on the NCA, the coalition takes the view that it provides the ideal mechanism for review at the Commonwealth level. Unfortunately, the Parliament has failed fully and effectively to make use of this mechanism. Whilst acknowledging the initial difficulties in arriving at a modus vivendi between the Committee and the NCA which was finally achieved because of the goodwill on the part of both bodies, only two reports, 1985 and 1986, have been issued. I exhort the Committee to press on with the job and, in so doing, say that I regard the Committee's terms of reference to identify new mechanisms for law enforcement as equal, if not more important, than the NCA monitoring function.

Two matters on which the Committee's views would be of particular interest are a strategy for witness protection and an examination of trends and changes in criminal trends. The Committee has had witness protection on its agenda for a couple of years. In my view, its report is long overdue. I trust, therefore, that the Committee will complete its deliberations and bring forward proposals for a positive strategy in the near future.

The Opposition's position on the repeal section is abundantly clear. We are for permanency for the NCA and the consequent repeal of the sunset clause. We introduced such a measure in a Bill, not once but twice, in the Senate as far back as 1986 and certainly since the election. What was the Government's response to those Bills? It said, `The Opposition is jumping the gun. Before we introduce such a measure we must await a full review of the legislation so that the sunset clause repeal and implementation of the review can be finessed in a coordinated fashion'. At one stage the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) went so far as to say, `We will introduce it but we need time to draft the Bill'. He said that when we already had the Bill drafted for him, sitting on the table in the Senate. The Government seems to be too busy talking at the people to listen to what it is saying itself. Given the history of this Government, we have long since ceased to be surprised by such inconsistencies.

As to the proposed extended tenure for members, when the NCA was established in 1984, four years was set as the maximum period of appointment. A regular turnover of membership was seen to be an important safeguard against any possible abuse of power or corruption of the members. This view was based on overseas experience. I hasten to add that my comment is not intended to reflect adversely on any present or past member of the NCA. On the contrary, I am pleased to be able to say that Australia has been very fortunate to have had members of the highest calibre and integrity. In my view, there are reasonable grounds for the Chairman to be given an additional year to extend his term from four to five years. It is not a proposal that we would expect to have to face year in and year out. It is a one-off situation.

The factors supporting the extension are the need to establish a new organisation, requiring accommodation and staff, in Sydney, which meant that it took some time for the NCA to get fully under way, and the fact that the existing members were appointed only within the past 12 months or so. Accordingly, the Chairman's extension should ensure continuity of operations and facilitate a smoother transition to a new chairman in due course. I also note from a Press release by the Minister for Justice that the extension has the support of the Ministers on the NCA intergovernmental committee. I further understand that the proposal has the support of the Parliamentary Joint Statutory Committee on the NCA. The other two current members, other than the Chairman, are replacements for original appointees and because of the sunset clause could not be appointed for full four-year terms. The amendment will overcome this problem.

In regard to the amendments to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act-the proposals for judges issuing warrants to have the same indemnity from prosecution as sitting High Court judges and for certain procedures relating to telegram interception warrants to be brought into line with procedures for other warrants-are both desirable and, to my mind, non-controversial.

Both in a special report on Operation Silo released late in 1987 and in its annual report for 1986-87, the NCA has identified two amendments that it has recommended to the Government. These are, firstly, to overcome difficulties in determining what is a `material particular' for the purposes of a prosecution under section 33 for giving misleading evidence to the NCA and, secondly, to enable persons required to produce documents under section 29 to receive appearance expenses along the same lines as witnesses who appear before the NCA under section 28. The recommended amendments have not been taken up in the current Bill by the Government for reasons which are known only to the Government. I am concerned at the level of administrative efficiency within the sphere of government when these sorts of issues are not being dealt with. It was the Opposition that put up suggestions about how these matters ought to be dealt with. I am pleased that the Government has taken up one of the suggestions, which will be moved in committee.

In respect of the other suggestion, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has provided me with a short discussion paper outlining arguments which suggest that if such an amendment were to go ahead it should be coordinated with like amendments to State legislation underpinning the NCA Act. The discussion paper also raises other peripheral issues. In the circumstances, it seems to me there would be merit in leaving this matter in abeyance on the basis that it can be taken up again when Parliament considers legislation to implement the Parliamentary Joint Committee's report on the NCA's operations.

I see that the Chairman of the Committee is in the chamber. He may have a look at that matter as well. It also occurs to me that the issue of `materiality' would probably arise in the review of the Commonwealth Crimes Act being undertaken under the direction of Sir Harry Gibbs, the former Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia. If this is the case, I would request the Attorney to make Sir Harry's views known as part of the longer term review of the NCA Act. The Government has accepted the payment of appearance expenses for persons producing documents to the NCA and, as I said, I will move such an amendment in the committee stage.

The Government should have been addressing both of these matters and giving the NCA a proper and considered response. It should not have been left for the Opposition to raise these matters, although I am happy we have come to a sensible conclusion on one of them. I reiterate the coalition's support for the repeal of the NCA's sunset clause. It is long-standing coalition policy. We initiated such a Bill on two occasions in the Senate only to see our Bill not debated. We support the continuation of the NCA on a permanent basis. it was a coalition initiative. I am happy to give the Opposition's support to the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: That inquiry was not established by the Fraser Government to look at organised crime; it was an attack on the trade union movement. It took political action to establish the inquiry against trade unions. We all know what happened: the Fraser Government got a very hot potato dropped in its lap when the extent of the criminal use of the taxation system-and indeed criminal it was-was exposed by the Costigan Royal Commission. Even knowing, as a result of the evidence given to the Costigan Royal Commission, the extent of criminality and the extent of crime involving taxation fraud, the Fraser Government did nothing about it.

So I find it surprising in debates of this kind when any member of the Opposition talks about law and order and conservative policies involving law and order and organised crime. The truth of the matter is that in the Opposition's 30-odd years of government in the postwar period it never did anything about this area except talk. That can be well contrasted with the performance of the present Government, which since 1983 has, by legislation introduced and passed by this House, mounted the greatest attack on organised crime in this country's history. That is an unarguable proposition. The legislation is through the Parliament, it is on the books, it is working, it is effective.

Despite the Government's attack in this area there has been opposition from the conservative parties. I suppose the Cash Transaction Reports Bill is a great example of that. It is designed to follow the money trail so that criminal actions cannot be operated through banking systems. It is designed to stop the cash flow coming from criminal activities being laundered through the legitimate use of banking facilities. While that legislation was going through we heard speeches about the effect on banks. I recall that in the debate on the Bill the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), referred to the cost to banks. He said that the banks should not have to keep records. It is a nonsense to suggest that it would not cost the community to stop organised crime. Organised crime costs the community a great deal of money; legislation to stop organised crime has a cost factor attached to it. As I said earlier, I am often surprised at the rhetoric I hear about the attack on organised crime and what the Liberal Party of Australia do in government. I simply draw the House's attention to its record. It never did anything by way of legislation. That contrasts greatly with what this Government has done.

The National Crime Authority was established because of the perceived failure of existing police forces in this country. That is not to say that the existing police forces, be they State or Federal, have not been effective in dealing with community crime; that is, crime which involves offences against the person, street offences and drug trafficking at a minor level. The State police forces and the Federal police force have never had the capacity seriously to handle organised crime in this country. I guess that is understandable. Their resources have been limited. Indeed, community pressures on State police forces are for them to handle the day to day community criminal activities which are constantly reported to local police stations.

A second factor is that in our traditional methods police are reactive in their approach to crime; they are not proactive. Police respond to complaints that offences have been committed and regard their task as being completed when the person who has committed the offence has been apprehended and placed before the courts. To tackle organised crime seriously we need an organisation which has a far greater and very specific role which will home in on the major intrastate and interstate activities of organised crime. We know from the Williams, Stewart, Woodward and Costigan royal commissions, among others, that the extent of organised crime in this country was never recognised by government. It was never recognised by the major police forces of this country.

From my experience as Chairman of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority I have had a window opened to me in the last four months which has enabled me to look into an area which I never believed existed in this country, and that is despite my serving 10 years in the Victorian police force. Having that window open to me, I have been astonished at the high degree of involvement, the organisational structure and the extent of organised crime in this country. I guess the great problem we as a Parliament and as a nation not only face today but will face increasingly in the future is the increasing internationalisation of crime.

In a country with 16 1/2 million people, a high per capita income and a high standard of living, and probably because we are surrounded by the Indian Ocean and the Pacific Ocean, we might have thought we were exempt from the Cosa Nostra, the Triads and the other organised groups well known overseas. For many years we laboured under false premises in thinking that we could always escape the attention of such organised criminal groups. Yet we know increasingly today that we have not escaped their attentions. For example, we know now that there are in Australia groupings of people ethnically organised, family organised, who have immediate and strong links with their international cousins in their countries of origin. We know that money flows are laundered through Australia to international locations. We know that money derived from criminal activities is being placed in legitimate investments through banking systems. We know that those people, having moved into legitimate market areas, are then protected by that legitimacy and by their use of normal banking and financial systems and we know that, having achieved that status, they become harder and harder to track down.

We know that if one is involved in one of the major crime organisations in Australia today one's life is not worth a crumpet. We know that there is an increasing number of bodies found in dark lanes. These people have died because of their awareness and knowledge of organised crime in this country. Recently in Sydney there has been a large number of deaths of well-known criminals. They have been slaughtered in the streets of Sydney, which has become fashionable when organised criminal groups fall out. We, as politicians, are constantly being asked by constituents to stop crime. We are constantly being asked that the Parliament pass laws which will ensure that such activities cease. We would be less than honest with ourselves as politicians and less than honest as a parliament if we did not spread the message to our constituents and to Australia as a whole that it is too late to say that we can stop organised crime in this country. Past governments have failed to recognise the extent of organised crime which has enabled the criminal tentacles to get through the system in this country. It is too late to say to the people whom we represent that we can stop organised crime. If we are honest with ourselves, we can only say as parliamentarians that we can only do that which is possible to ensure that the growth of crime is limited. We can say as a parliament that we will pass those laws necessary to hinder and to impose restraints upon criminal activities. We can say that we will pass those laws necessary in order to establish commissions such as the National Crime Authority and which will give such bodies sufficient powers to lift the veil of secrecy, of legitimacy, that many of these people have and to expose them for what they are, criminals.

Having had that window of organised crime exposed to me in the last few months as Chairman of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority it has become apparent that the only way the problem can be solved is through a national approach. The State police forces are internal in thought and local in operation. Because of the history of curruption and crime in this country there is in all State police forces a degree of suspicion about other police forces. I guess that is understandable in the context of the history of this country. Without referring too much to the events that are currently occurring in Queensland, one only has to read the newspapers on the evidence being given to Mr Fitzgerald to understand why State police forces have been hesitant and cautious about their dealings with other State police force bodies. That includes the Australian Federal Police who operate under the same difficulties.

It seems obvious to me why a body such as the National Crime Authority had to arise in this country. It is also obvious that unless we maintain and continue to strengthen the operation of that body the State and other existing police forces will not be capable of having much effect on organised crime. I say that without wanting to criticise the operation of the State police forces. I have nothing but the highest respect for my former colleagues in the police force in Victoria who are still in the police force whom I know to be men and women of integrity. They are doing their best within the laws available to them to stop crime. They are the first to recognise that they cannot go beyond State boundaries. They cannot do the sorts of things the National Crime Authority does. I agree with the critics of police forces generally who argue that we cannot as a parliament-and I believe State parliaments cannot-give State police forces extensive powers until such time as those police forces can demonstrate to the community that they are beyond corruption, that they will use fairly any extended powers that many now seek and that they will not use those powers wrongly. Until the police forces can demonstrate that, the need is emphasised for an overriding National Crime Authority body operating over and above the existing organised police forces of this country.

There are other matters on which I will speak more fully when the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority brings down its evaluation report, which we are hoping to do in May this year. We have set ourselves a fairly heavy task in that the Committee concurrently has running an inquiry into witness protection. I am pleased to report to the Parliament that we have probably finished taking all the evidence we need to take on witness protection and we hope to start drafting that report shortly. The evaluation report on the National Crime Authority is in draft form at the moment. We hope to have hearings early next month. At this stage there appear to be very few submissions coming in from people who are prepared to comment on the effectiveness or otherwise of the National Crime Authority. We hope that those people who have a view on the National Crime Authority, favourable or otherwise, will take steps to approach the Committee. They can either put their views in writing or they can approach the Committee to seek to give evidence before it so that we can bring down a report which fully reflects the views of all the groups in Australia who have that interest and which is a full report on the current operations of the National Crime Authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do not rush it just because of this repeal Bill.

—My colleague the shadow Attorney-General suggests that we do not rush it. I can guarantee that we will not rush it. For the honourable member's information we wrote late last year to all of the bodies which gave evidence to the Senate hearing seeking their viewpoints three years down the track. We got very little or no response. We have again written to all those groups seeking further responses, and again I am disappointed with the response we are getting. We have also advertised in Australian newspapers for submissions. There is nothing more we can do as a committee to make the various groups in Australia aware of the desire of the Committee to seek that information. Perhaps one can say that that lack of interest, if I can call it that, is an obvious response from the community that it is satisfied with the operations of the Authority itself. We still intend to speak to several people in order to get their viewpoints.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier I said that as a member of the Government I have nothing but pride in standing in this House whenever the subject of crime is debated. Our record is exemplary. I am proud not just of the National Crime Authority but of the Proceeds of Crime Bill-again a first in this country's history-the Cash Transaction Reports Bill, with which I have already dealt, and the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill. For many years the need for telephone intercepts and powers has been discussed in this country. I recall that back in the 1960s when I was a serving policeman this subject was discussed in Victoria. Yet it took a Labor government to introduce such legislation. There was no rhetoric, there was no talk about it, we just did it. We also introduced the Proceeds of Crime Bill. Why did it take so long to pass legislation which takes away from a criminal the proceeds of that criminal activity? It took a Labor government to do it. I suggest to the shadow Attorney-General that policies are simple to draw up and words can be very shallow. All political parties can use words. They can make them flowery and they can make them politically attractive, and that is what political parties like to do. As a citizen and as a political opponent of the honourable member for Flinders I will say that his words are shallow no matter how he says them, until he can demonstrate to me and to the rest of the community that he will not just talk about the problem but will support this Government's approach to anti-crime legislation. As a member of this Government I have not had it fully demonstrated that he will support us. His actions on the telephone intercept legislation and the cash transaction legislation are two examples of that. It will not be proved to me until, if by some bad chance the Opposition manages to win government one day, his Government brings down legislation because, as I said, words are cheap. Standing in this House and saying what he wants to do stands against his record of having done nothing when he has had the chance. I do not think it is ever fair for any member of the Opposition to stand in this place and suggest that the Government is not taking the bit between its teeth. It has acted better and more fully than any government in Australia's history on the attack against major organised crime.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Has the Minister seen media reports this morning regarding coal settlements between Canadian companies and the Japanese steel mills? Can the Minister inform the House on the current status of negotiations on Australian coking coal exports to Japan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and for the close interest he pays to coal industry problems. Yes, I have seen the report. Negotiations between Japanese steel mills and Australian exporters for coking coal sales for the Japanese fiscal year 1988-commencing 1 April-are at an advanced and delicate stage. Australian producers have been seeking a significant price increase this year, the first after five successive price reductions. The reason for this is that the demand for steel worldwide is strong, and the Japanese mills have achieved a dramatic resurgence in profitability, and this is expected to be sustained throughout Japanese fiscal year 1988. The impact of strong demand for coking coal by the steel industry around the world has been accentuated by diversion of lower quality coking coals into equally strong domestic steaming coal markets, where the coals are used for power generation. On the supply side, output of both steaming and coking coal has been constrained by management decisions to curtail recurring financial losses by closing mines or limiting operations. These output constraints are evident in all major coal exporting countries and are the natural consequence of the cost-price squeeze that has afflicted the coal industry in recent years and cost so many jobs in New South Wales and Queensland. Coal prices achieved in recent international spot sales and open tenders have reflected this tightening of the market.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much conversation in the chamber.

—The Opposition is not interested in the coal industry, and that is pretty obvious. It is important for me to emphasise that coal supply negotiations, and particularly pricing terms, are matters for the commercial parties. I should stress also that coal prices to the Japanese market are almost invariably denominated in United States dollars, and any price increase achieved in fiscal year 1988 would need to be substantial to equate to the Japanese fiscal year 1987 price converted into Australian dollars. Since last year's settlement, the exchange rate has firmed from 0.65c to around 0.73c or 0.74c, a move requiring a price increase of more than $US5 a tonne to compensate. Of course, the fiscal year 1987 price was markedly lower than in previous years and clearly inadequate to provide an appropriate return on investment. The current firmness in the market therefore does not diminish, in any way, the imperative that the industry persevere with efficiency improvement and cost reduction in order to retain its competitiveness.

ANSWER.PARA: The annual negotiations in Japan are proceeding towards a conclusion. I am hopeful of an outcome that is fair and satisfactory to both sides, having full regard to current market realities. I can confirm that there have been recent developments in negotiations with certain North American producers. As we understand the situation, the absolute price increases being quoted do not reflect anything like the full value of the offers that evidently have been made by the mills, as substantial reclassification of coal qualities is also involved. For example, the Canadians have been offered `incentive tonnage' totalling just over one million tonnes. However, there is some question as to whether the Canadian firms involved are in a position to supply such increases. We understand that the Canadians have, to date, refused to settle on the terms offered unless they receive a written assurance that any higher price negotiated by the Australians will flow on to them. No settlement has yet been signed or agreed. I gather the Japanese offer to the Canadians has, if anything, strengthened the resolve of the Australian exporters to pursue their original claims, the offer being a clear confirmation that the steel industry recognises that substantial turnaround in market conditions.

I thank the honourable member for his question and those people on my side of the House, as opposed to the Opposition, who take an interest in the coal industry and in our bids to get higher prices for coal.

—Can the Minister for Industrial Relations advise the House what steps the Government has taken through its wages policy to protect the position of low wage earners in recent years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is concerned about the position of low wage earners. I thank the honourable member for Hawker for her question which indicates her interest in this topic along with that of all other members on this side of the House. The Government has put into effect its concern about low wage earners in pursuing a wages policy in difficult economic circumstances which has necessarily involved overall some real reduction in the level of wages. But in that context we have been concerned to ensure that low wage earners were protected as much as possible. That is demonstrated by such things as the first tier increases in the current wage system which have involved a $10 increase and a $6 increase, both obviously flat money increases rather than percentage increases and providing higher percentage increases in pay to low wage earners than to high wage earners. It has clearly been a greater protection to lower paid workers than to higher paid workers to have it in that flat money form.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, the second tier increases that apply under the present system have generally been of the order of 4 per cent. But some industries have been biased towards looking after low wage earners. For instance, in the Commonwealth Public Service, although the average is 4 per cent, the top paid public servants have received only 3 per cent. At the bottom end there has been a 5 per cent increase. Indeed, for the very lowest paid public servants on the lowest classification there has been over a 10 per cent increase. In some industries there have been supplementary payments introduced as part of the second tier increase. Supplementary payments are a form of minimum over-award payment, in effect, and they have increased the position of lowest paid workers in the industries where they have been introduced, such as the transport industry, the timber industry and manufacturing grocers. They will also apply probably in the near future in such important industries as the retail trade, the furnishing trades and the textile and clothing industry.

The Government has also supported the spread of occupational superannuation. Generally that has been around the 3 per cent mark but in some industries that has applied in a way which again has given greater increases to lower paid workers on a percentage basis. Thus, in the Australian Government employment area we have, for our own employees, provided an overall enhancement of superannuation of 3 per cent. However, for top paid public servants and other Australian Government employees, the amount is only 2 per cent while at the bottom, for lower paid public servants and other Australian Government employees, there is a flat money amount of $11.50 or around 4 per cent.

All this has to be put in the context also of changes to the tax system. A couple of cases have been deliberately biased towards low paid workers. Changes to the social wage, which the Prime Minister elaborated on yesterday, greatly enhance the position of low paid workers in this country, particularly the dynamic family assistance scheme which is greatly increasing the position of low paid workers.

I will just quickly indicate the effect of those provisions. I will give a few examples. An adult male worker without a family, receiving average earnings in the fabricated metals products industry, who has received a superannuation payment of 3 per cent along with the wage increase from the current wage system has had a real increase of one per cent in his real after tax income since this Government has been in office. Let us take the case of a machinist in the furnishing trades who has a dependent spouse and two dependent children, and is also receiving superannuation and is entitled to the family assistance scheme. That person has received a 16.9 per cent increase in real after tax income since this Government came to office. Take the case of a woman working in the textile industry, who is receiving average pay from that industry, who has no dependent spouse but has two dependent children and who also receives superannuation and is entitled to payments from the family assistance scheme. The increase in real after tax income for that woman is 18.6 per cent.

Leaving aside the enormously important family assistance scheme, one can see that because of the various ways in which we have sought to assist low paid workers they have, in large measure, been protected from the reduction in real wages which has occurred overall. But on top of that, with the family assistance scheme there has been an increase in their real after tax income of extraordinary proportions. Honourable members should remember that on top of that we have to take into account other improvements in the social wage.

There is no doubt whatever that this Government's concern about low paid workers in this country has been well and truly put into effect. Their position has been greatly enhanced when they have dependent children. Even when there are no dependent children their position has been maintained and even enhanced.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The dramatic impact on Australians of the Hawke Government's proposed changes to the tax treatment of superannuation.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some five weeks ago we had a debate in this House as a matter of public importance on the Government's proposed changes and increases in taxation in the field of superannuation. Since then two most important events have occurred. Last Saturday's election results demonstrated right across Australia that the policies of this Government have been absolutely repudiated by the Australian people. The voters took this course of action because they are sick of having governments which constantly put their hands in the pockets of the people. They voted the way they did in electorates such as Minchinbury because they can no longer survive in a social and economic system brought upon the nation by five years of Labor Party government. Next Saturday in the Port Adelaide by-election the Government will see yet again a repudiation of its policies, when the people will have the opportunity to determine whether or not they want to pay more tax on superannuation. But the situation did not end at that point. The other day I asked a question of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) about why he believed that those who had superannuation were tax cheats, and by implication those who sold superannuation cover were tax cheats; why he believed that the entire system had to be changed; and, above all, why he said that taxation on superannuation was inevitable, despite the earlier comments by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).

SPEECH.PARA: What has taken place in this House over recent weeks demonstrates conclusively that as at May 1988 the Government will have only one fundamental objective-to take from superannuation every possible tax cent it can get its filthy hands on. That is what the Australian people are sick and tired of. On the one hand the Government says, `Join 3 per cent superannuation productivity schemes. Get into superannuation. We want people to save for their long term financial security in retirement'. They are all perfectly valid objectives, but beneath the reality one detects the snake-like appearance of a Labor government that really only wants to say to people, `Join a superannuation scheme so we can tax you more'.

We are told that the purpose of this tax is to rationalise the arrangements for corporate taxation. As the Prime Minister said today at Question Time, `We have to look at taxing superannuation so we can rationalise the whole thing'. The part of my question the Prime Minister refused to answer was: if that is the case, why has the Government bothered to ask Dr Bettina Cass to involve herself in a very expensive and detailed inquiry into retirement incomes policy, the results of which, the Minister for Social Security told us the other day, would be available in June? `Mid-year' is exactly what he said. I do not think that May, in terms of the May mini-Budget, is mid-year. The Government has two inquiries concurrently into the same area of policy and has the effrontery to come into this House and claim that it has a properly co-ordinated retirement incomes policy. There is no way known to man or woman that one can possibly say in the context of taxation reform what should be done to superannuation unless a much wider perspective is taken of the role of superannuation reform in the totality of retirement incomes policy.

What are we going to have? We are going to have new taxes on superannuation in May and, in June or later, we are going to have a report from Dr Cass telling us how superannuation can fit into retirement income policy. She will probably make the most obvious observation, namely, that taxing superannuation at too high a rate will force people out of superannuation and not into it. On the basis of the Government's comments over the last five years, especially the comments made by none other than the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in May 1983, I would have thought that this was precisely the opposite direction to which the Government wanted to go.

In Port Adelaide there are 22,000 superannuants. But they are now all cheats. We will be telling the people of Port Adelaide, as we have done for some weeks, that they are all cheats because the Government and the Minister for Social Security claims that they are so. Thousands of people around Australia are selling superannuation schemes because they thought-and the Opposition believed-that they were working in the context of the law as it stands. But the mob of charlatans opposite prefers to regard these people as taxation frauds and cheats. Like many others, the people of Port Adelaide are joining the 3.2 million Australians who want to be financially independent in their retirement.

That independence is one of the objectives emphasised by the Government's own Economic Planning Advisory Council report entitled Economic Effects of an Ageing Population. The evidence in this report is clear. If Australia continues down its present road, where only 47 per cent of the work force has access to superannuation, we face not only the inexorable reality that within 20 years we will have an ageing population but also the very real difficulty, on the present level of economic growth, of being un- able to maintain pensions at their current levels. Any government planning for the future-a theme we hear so often from the Prime Minister and his stooges opposite-would have said, as I am saying now, `We want to encourage people to look for alternatives outside the government funded pension system'. Nobody disputes the fact that it is the role of the Government to provide a safety net, an underpinning, so nobody falls into poverty in retirement. That is a principle with which I hope all members of this House would agree. To then say, `We do not wish to make superannuation attractive enough for a long term investment' is outrageous. It is absolutely contrary to the principles of what superannuation is meant to be all about.

For the benefit of the House and as a basis for this debate, let us agree on what we are talking about. I said in this House some weeks ago in the debate on the superannuation legislation that superannuation is a system of deferred income for genuine retirement purposes. Designed to maintain an adequate standard of living after retirement, it should also result in decreased dependence on the social security system. They are the objectives of superannuation. Independence from the social security system and adequate income in retirement are the objectives for which we work.

When we talk about self-provision in retirement, what do we mean? We mean that the long term objective must be to encourage the entire work force, not just the rich, but the ordinary blue collar workers in places like Port Adelaide, to feel that the door is open, that they are being encouraged to save for their retirement so that they will have a degree of financial dependence, which this Government wants to deny them. Underneath it all what the socialists opposite really want is to have everybody locked into a pension system by which government, and government alone, can determine the capacity of people to have financial independence in retirement. No other reason can justify the direction of the Government's current policy and approach.

If the Government were honest, it would face the fact that it cannot talk about reducing personal income tax, on the one hand, and increasing the rate of superannuation tax, on the other hand. One does not need to be a genius to know that suddenly the point is reached where it is no longer marginally worth while for the average Australian worker seriously to consider superannuation. Instead of seeing a growth in superannuation what the Government will guarantee will be a constant flow-out of existing funds, and making it very difficult for people to join new funds.

The Government, under its new regulations-which the Opposition supports on this point at least-is asking people, who are meant to be saving for long term retirement, in 30 or 40 years, to deny themselves income but not to expect to get any reasonable taxation support. Most people today have to spend their income. Because of the declining standard of living in this society over the last five years, the ordinary people of Australia, the ordinary people who used to vote for Labor, can no longer survive. They certainly cannot afford superannuation if they lose the capacity to consume, without taxation support at an adequate level.

In May 1983, with the aura of change and the need for a long term policy, the Government introduced various administrative arrangements under which it was able to hide a significant increase in superannuation taxation. It was a 30 per cent lump sum tax, equivalent to 19 per cent on the current marginal tax rates. The Government is now saying that it will increase the tax rate even further. That will produce the conflict I referred to. The ultimate result will be that far fewer people will take out superannuation than has been the case in the past.

The Prime Minister came in here and said that he was making three promises. He said that the Government would not consider any changes which would impact adversely on already accrued superannuation benefits. What does that mean? Does it mean that the changes will not be retrospective? I sincerely hope so. The Opposition will not accept retrospectivity in this regard-ever. I make that absolutely clear. The commitments that people have made over 10, 20 or 30 years should be respected by whoever is the government of the day. The Government has no right, at any stage, to change the game upon which those people have made their decision in the past.

Let us remember this: even if the Government draws a line on its ledger and says, `We will not tax anything prior to that date and will only tax investment income after that date', it should not kid itself. There is a degree of retrospectivity in that. No fund manager can discriminate between the decisions he made five or 10 years ago and income which is still being generated in the future.

The Prime Minister also said that the Government would not make any changes which would stop people from taking lump sum superannuation benefits. What does that mean? Does it mean that the Government will still allow people to take 100 per cent lump sums? Does it suggest that lump sums will be cut down to 50 per cent? Does the Prime Minister realise the impact this could have on people who are trying to pay off their houses, their commitments, so that they can enter retirement on at least a level playing field? The correlation in all the evidence is clear: if one does not own one's own home when one goes into retirement poverty is a reality at the front door, a reality which will continue because of the policies of this Government. When one relates it to issues such as the capacity of Australians to save, it is clear that the rate of household savings in Australia is now falling at the fastest rate since the war.

One of the obvious reasons why it is falling is that people cannot afford to eat, and if they cannot afford to live they cannot afford to save. Yet it is in that environment that the Government once again is looking for $1 billion or, if it is lucky, $2 billion to tax out of superannuation fund investment accounts. It has not said anything about the 30 per cent tax on lump sums. Are we to have that as well? Of course, the people of Port Adelaide, the people of New South Wales and the people of Western Australia-even the people of Kew in Victoria last Saturday-had these thoughts in their minds. There is no doubt that anybody over the age of 45, in an environment of relatively high inflation, has every reason to be mortally afraid of his future in retirement.

The one thing such people ask of government is stability and the financial, social and economic environment in which to save for their future and be independent of government. They want the Government to provide the ultimate fall-back position if a desperate situation occurs, because the sad fact is that, even with superannuation, if inflation continues as it is through the rest of this decade and to the end of the century, many people who have superannuation today will still ultimately have to go in to the social security system. But the longer we encourage them to stay out of that system the greater the benefit to Australia. Above all, those people will have the degree of financial independence for which they have worked and saved. That is their right and the Government has no right to take it from them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

May I remind the House of the Liberal coalition policies over the 30 years of its reign, or more accurately 80 years. Let me go over some of the points that have been made. The Prime Minister has made the Government's position on superannuation clear in three respects. They show that whilst 50 per cent of males receive superannuation only a quarter of females do. What, might I ask, did the coalition do about this when it was in government? Absolutely nothing. It showed its real concern by the policies that it implemented, which did absolutely zero in this area. Contrast that with what we have done.

I also point out that the statistics show that it is the people in the most highly paid professions who overwhelmingly benefit from superannuation. According to the statistics, three-quarters of male managers, administrators and professionals get superannuation cover but only 30 per cent of labourers and related workers get superannuation cover. The proposition on this side of the House is that superannuation should be extended to all. We started it and we are doing it for male and female; young and old. The statistics also show that 70 per cent of people who earn more than $520 a week get superannuation cover but that only 30 per cent of people who earn less than $440 get superannuation cover. That highlights the hypocrisy of the Opposition's stand.

No-one who is currently a member of a superannuation scheme needs to be terrified by the gutter tactics of the Opposition. We are extending superannuation. The point about superannuation and why there should be a review of it is that superannuation tax concessions cost the Australian taxpayer more than $3 billion a year. We have pledged to continue the concessionality of superannuation, but the Opposition is saying that we should not review it. It is saying, in the light of the business tax review, that we should not review it, that we should leave it out. What sheer and utter hypocrisy!

The Opposition spokesman suggested that we have filthy hands in relation to superannuation. I say that the Opposition has a filthy record on taxation per se. The Opposition, when in government, got into bed with its mates and allowed tax avoidance to grow. It allowed Mr and Mrs Average Australian to bear an unfair burden. It did not give a damn about salaried workers, it did not give a damn about wage earners, and it did not give a damn about Mr and Mrs Average. That is its record, yet it accuses us of having dirty hands in relation to superannuation.

The real point about the matter of public importance raised by the Opposition is that it is miffed about the real progress that I mentioned earlier, that has been achieved through the accord and by the Government's economic strategy to create more jobs and combat Australia's balance of payments. Opposition members are buoyed by the results of the New South Wales State election on Saturday, and perhaps they should be. But since the Opposition's defeat at the last Federal election what policy has it brought in? It claims to have a new policy, a new vision for all Australians, a new vision for the average worker. Where are the policies? After nine months of a defeat where are they? Where is the economic policy of the Leader of the Opposition? Where is the taxation policy? Will the Opposition spokesman table the policy? Of course he cannot table it-because it has not been produced.

The real difference between the Government and the Opposition on economic and management issues is that we have made the changes with the least impact on all Australians. We have sheeted home a phenomenal increase in the number of jobs. It is true that we still have unemployment, but to us on this side of the House that is a challenge to overcome. For the Opposition the unemployed are merely fodder, whose numbers are to be increased and decreased at whim in order to manage the economy. We have restructured the economy the Labor way-by increasing jobs and by increasing our commitment to social justice.

Look at some of the things we have done in our five years in office and that we are pledged to continue to do. We introduced the family assistance package that the shadow Minister for Social Security got the location of so wrong. It is probably one of the most radical reforms to help those really in need ever introduced, and it was introduced in recent times by a Labor Government. We have looked after pensions in difficult times. The Opposition when in government provided pensioners with a real decline in living standards. Their living standards went down under the Fraser years. We have increased their pensions from 22.7 per cent of average weekly earnings to the 25 per cent that it is today, and this has been done in hard times. I said that the tax system has been reformed. Apparently the Opposition finds it somehow objectionable that we should continue to want to reform and lift the tax burden of all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are they? Where are your mates?

—Let me say that it is interesting to note that on industry policy and assistance to industry, before the last election the Opposition supported every Government proposition, but during the election the Opposition decided that it would wipe out all forms of government assistance to industry, one of the potential engine-rooms under Labor for increasing employment. SPEECH.PARA: Let me turn to health issues. Perhaps one of the most shameful things about the Opposition is that in every avaricious campaign by specialists that we get locked into where does it stand for the ordinary men and women of Australia who need medical attention from specialists?
