The Crimes (Torture) Bill will enable Australia to ratify the Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment which was signed by Australia on 10 December 1985. The Convention, generally known as the Torture Convention, came into force on 26 June 1987, 30 days after the twentieth country, Denmark, deposited its instrument of ratification. As Attorney-General, I announced the Government's decision to ratify the Convention at the Human Rights Congress in Sydney on 25 September 1987. Ratification of the Convention by Australia has been the subject of consultation with the States in the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General and there is general agreement with this decision. Torture is an abhorrent practice and much work has been done in the councils of the United Nations to find practical ways of combating it. Australia has played a prominent part in such work and this Bill should be seen as a part of that process. In accordance with the provisions of the Convention, its main purpose is to deny a safe haven in Australia to any person who, while acting officially, or at the instigation or behest of a person so acting, is involved in the torture of a person in another country. There are currently 28 parties to the Convention, each of which has undertaken similar obligations to those embodied in this Bill.
As a party to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, Australia is already bound by the obligation in article 7 of that Covenant, which provides:

No one shall be subjected to torture or to cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. In particular, no one shall be subjected without his free consent to medical or scientific experimentation.

The Government takes the view that the laws of the States and Territories are already adequate to fulfil this obligation and the obligations of the Torture Convention in so far as acts committed within Australia are concerned. The Bill does not, therefore, apply to acts within Australia. Instead, the substantive provisions in clause 6 of the Bill apply to any act of torture as defined in the Convention which is committed anywhere in the world outside Australia. The Bill does not apply retrospectively to acts of torture committed before the legislation comes into force. Australian domestic law will be applied to an Australian citizen and to any person present in Australia who has committed an act of torture as defined in the Convention. The law to be applied will, in substance, be the law of the State or Territory where the offender is prosecuted.

In the Government's view, adoption of the well-developed criminal law of the States and Territories is a preferable course to the creation of new Commonwealth law to deal with these very particular and, in the Australian context, hopefully rare circumstances. It should be noted, however, that the provisions of State and Territory legislation, and the relevant common law principles, will be applied as Federal law.

Clauses 8, 9 and 10 of the Bill make necessary incidental provision for the handling of any prosecutions which, by virtue of section 68 of the Judiciary Act, will be heard in State courts. Clause 11 will preclude the raising of defences of exceptional circumstances or superior orders. Clause 13 recognises the obligation under article 6 of the Convention to allow an alleged offender who is not an Australian citizen access to his or her country's diplomatic or consular representatives. The remaining clauses ensure that State and Territory laws are not displaced, make appropriate provision for the Act's application and adopt the Convention's definition of torture.

It remains for me to explain why it was considered unnecessary to include certain other provisions which might appear to be called for by the Convention. The obligations under article 5 to establish jurisdiction when offences are committed on an Australian ship or aircraft are already fulfilled by the Crimes at Sea Act 1979 and the Crimes (Aircraft) Act 1963. The other categories in that article are, I believe, encompassed by the Bill or by existing State and Territory law. Obligations in relation to extradition are fulfilled by our extradition law, treaties and practice. Obligations under article 16 in relation to cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment which do not amount to torture are, in the Government's view, fulfilled by State and Territory criminal law, and the obligation under article 14 to provide for fair and adequate compensation for the victim of an act of torture is met by State criminal injuries compensation legislation and by common law rights in tort.

The passage of this Bill will be a significant step in the international effort to combat torture. Whether or not the occasion ever arises for the legislation to be invoked, its existence will be a clear indication to the international community that Australia will never become a safe haven for those who breach fundamental human rights. It will also provide a practical means of dealing with any situation where a person who is alleged to have committed acts of torture overseas is found within Australian territory. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and I commend the Bill to the House.

The purpose of this Bill is to reconstitute the Australian Honey Board with revised functions and powers, a changed membership structure, and enhanced accountability to the honey industry, which provides the Board's funds through levies and an export charge. The legislative changes required to this end involve also repeal of the Honey Industry Act 1962, which is the Board's present charter, and appropriate amendments to the Honey Levy Acts (Nos 1 and 2) 1962 as well as to the Honey Export Charge Act 1973. These amendments are being introduced by separate Bills, so that a legislative package of four Bills is involved.

In seeking to reform the Australian Honey Board, the Government wishes to apply to this body the policy principles which are being progressively applied to all primary industry statutory marketing authorities. These principles were enunciated in January 1986 in a White Paper on the reform of the authorities in question. Their aim is to make these bodies more effective, improve their accountability and enlarge their autonomy while ensuring ministerial oversight at the strategic level. In applying this policy to the Australian Honey Board, the Government has taken care to do so in a way appropriate to the circumstances of the honey industry. This industry is of modest size compared with our major rural industries, but it supplies virtually all domestic honey requirements and also exports a substantial part of its annual output. In 1986-87 honey exports contributed $16.6m to Australia's export income.

The proposed changes to the structure and charter of the Honey Board were decided on after a detailed review of the Board's operations since its establishment some 25 years ago under the Honey Industry Act 1962. In the course of this review, extensive discussions took place with honey industry organisations in which the options discussed ranged from abolishing the Board to leaving it unchanged. The Government has concluded that there is still a role for a statutory marketing authority for the Australian honey industry, but believes that the present structure and charter of the Australian Honey Board are not conducive to fulfilment of that role with optimal results. The Board's current charter is too broad, as evidenced by the fact that some specific powers of the Board have seen little or no use in recent years. Its current membership of 10 is too large for an authority with a small budget, while the fact that Board members are elected or nominated to represent sectional interests limits the range of professional skills available to the Board. Moreover, the Board's operational autonomy is unduly restricted by requirements for ministerial approval in matters of relative detail.

All of these shortcomings have been addressed in the changes proposed by the Bill. Under these changes, the new Board's role will be focused solely on two defined objectives. These are to maximise returns to the honey industry from exports, and to generate a greater demand for Australian honey both in Australia and overseas. In practical terms, this means that the restructured Board will be required to direct its attention and resources to promotional activity, and to support of the export marketing activities of the industry by assistance to honey exporters and a judicious regulation of their operations to prevent undesirable trading conduct.

In the latter regard, it is the wish of the Government that the Board should keep its export regulatory or control activities to a minimum, allowing exporters as much freedom in their operations as is consistent with the interests of the industry as a whole. To ensure that this policy principle is observed, the Board will be required to review the operation of its export controls annually and to report the outcome of its review to the two principal organisations of the honey industry, namely, the Federal Council of Australian Apiarists Associations, the FCAAA, and the Honey Packers Association of Australia, the HPAA. These organisations are referred to in the Bill as the `producers' organisation' and the `packers' organisation' respectively, and those terms are also used in this speech for the sake of brevity.

To enable the Board to exercise an appropriate degree of control over exports, the Bill provides that exporters of honey must be licensed by the Board. At present, these exporters must also be licensed, but the Board only recommends the issue of licences, while the power to grant them resides with the Minister or his delegate. Criteria for the granting of licences are specified in the Bill, which also provides for recourse to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal where a person is dissatisfied with a decision of the Board in the matter of licensing. Export licences will be subject to terms and conditions determined by the Board. In this regard, the Board will retain its present power to set minimum prices below which honey may not be exported. Similarly, it will retain the power to appoint agents in overseas countries and to require all exporters to make their transactions through these agents. It will also be open to the new Board, if it deems it necessary, to operate other modes of control such as export permits or time limits on forward contracts entered into by exporters. As already noted, however, the Board will be expected to provide reasons for such controls.

In keeping with the Government's policy for statutory marketing authorities, the Board will be required to prepare a five-year corporate plan and to review it at least once a year. Similarly, it will have to prepare annual operational plans. In both cases, the Board will have to consult with the producers' and packers' organisations in the preparation of these plans. The plans will require the Minister's approval and form the basis of the Board's operations. As a further accountability requirement the annual reports of the Board will, amongst other things, have to assess the extent to which the Board's corporate and operational plan objectives were met. The Board will also be formally accountable to the peak industry bodies, namely, the Federal Council of Australian Apiarists Associations and the Honey Packers Association of Australia. The Board's chairperson will be required to report to meetings of these bodies after presentation of the Board's annual report to the Minister.

With regard to the structure of the new Board, it will be made up of eight members, namely, a chairperson and a Government member who will both be chosen and appointed by the Minister, and six other members who will be selected and nominated for appointment by a selection committee to be established as specified in the Bill. These six members will be selected for their expertise in a range of fields relevant to the functions of the Board. Selection committee membership will consist of six persons appointed by the Minister, namely, a chairperson independent of any particular interest, two nominees each from the producer and packer sectors of the honey industry, and a person with professional staff selection experience who is to be nominated by the four industry members of the committee.

Transitional provisions are included in the Bill which will ensure that existing Board membership and export controls will continue until the proposed new structure is fully in place and operational. It is expected that this stage will be reached not later than 1 January next. It is the intention of the Government that the operation of the reconstituted Honey Board be reviewed after five years in a fundamental way and, accordingly, the Bill provides for termination of its constituting legislation after six years from its commencement. Mention was made earlier of proposed amendments to the honey levy and export charge Acts. These Acts generate the funds which finance the Board, and the projected amendments will give the peak organisations of the honey industry a formal right to influence the level of funding to be provided to the Board. In addition, they will create scope in the levy Acts to increase that funding beyond the present limit if the industry decides to seek an increase in the future.

The new arrangements I have outlined are not expected to impose any additional costs on the Commonwealth. Little change is anticipated in the cost to the industry of maintaining the Board. I am confident that this Bill and associated legislation will establish a more effective institutional basis for the honey industry with which to respond to future marketing challenges. I present the explanatory memorandum for this Bill and commend the Bill to honourable members.

It is further proposed to increase the maximum rate of levy that can be imposed to finance the activities of the Board from 2.2c to 5c per kilogram of honey. The operative rate as prescribed by regulation is now at the maximum permissible level, and a higher levy maximum will provide scope for raising the present operative rate as and when recommended by the industry in the future.

While the increased levy maximum will create scope for increasing the rate of the Honey Board component of the levy beyond its present level, no increase will take place until such time as the honey industry and the Board recommend that a higher rate be prescribed and the recommendation is implemented. TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are considering a paper brought down yesterday by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), who I am afraid is fast becoming the Minister for defence statements, reports and consultants. Given the emphasis of the Minister's statement yesterday, my guess is that in the near future we will also receive a statement on personnel matters from the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly). I cannot help thinking that defence analysts overseas with the responsibility for monitoring defence developments in Australia must be coming to the conclusion that Australia's main deterrent weapon is the 25-plus page parliamentary statements that the Minister is making fairly regularly lately.

SPEECH.PARA: As is always the case, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), the shadow Minister for Defence, has delivered a devastating critique of the Minister's statement. Yesterday he exposed once again the recycled announcements, myths and misrepresentations that unfortunately the Minister's statement contained. I will not go over the details of that critique but I would refer my colleague and constituents to the shadow Minister's earlier speech and to the one he delivered last month in response to the Minister's regional initiatives statement. I want instead to provide a guide to the euphemisms and double speak which have come to characterise this Government's defence statements. I do not blame the Minister for his rhetorical subterfuge; I simply sympathise with his impotence in an unsympathetic Cabinet which gives him no other recourse.

Let me provide a sample of my compilation of Labor defence euphemisms as shown in the Minister's statement yesterday. On page 3 the Minister told us that the White Paper program has survived Budget reviews `virtually unscathed'. `Virtually unscathed', I believe, should read that as a result of the last Budget the Minister would appreciate at least an additional five years notice of any threat to our security, if our adversaries would be so kind. On page 4 the Minister used one of his favourite phrases, `credible contingencies'. `Credible contingencies' are security threats which, fortuitously, fit our inadequate Budget and capabilities. On page 8 we heard of the planning concept of `the most likely areas of operation'. This phrase reflects the `please invade between the flags' thinking of some sections of the Department of Defence. That entry should be cross-referred with the `credible contingencies' one.

Referring to the system of joint force commander, the Minister used the phrase `should be further developed in several important directions' on page 19 of the statement. That should read, `The system is inadequate to its tasks and, if it is not to fail in a time of serious threat, needs immediate review'. On the same page we are provided with probably the most provocative euphemism of the paper, given the current defence personnel crisis-`fluctuating separation rates'. `Fluctuating separation rates' is a deeply embarrassed government's way of referring to the unprecedented levels of service resignations which have now compromised the operational capacity of the defence forces. Really, there is no denying that. The description on page 21 of the work by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel as `very complex' means simply that the Minister has been unable to make any progress in tackling the underlying problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —She has been cocooned when she has visited bases.

—That is right. Another phrase, `particularly adept resource management', which is used on page 22, is a polite admission that the Minister has been forced by an inadequate budget to stretch already overstretched manpower and equipment even further. The use of the phrase `financial realism' on the same page reflects the new consensus which characterises the defence debate. `Financial realism' means acquiescence in apathy and the absence of political support or will in Cabinet for defence spending.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Minister confesses, on page 27, that it is `difficult to quantify overall savings' from efficiency programs he really means that he has made some `satisfying' guesstimates about his budget. When he says, on the same page, that the White Paper's objectives `can be achieved without growth in the defence appropriations' the Minister is giving us advance notice that he has failed again in the Budget review and we should not expect any good news for defence in May or August. Finally, when the Minister refers on page 27 to the `professionalism of the men and women of the Australian Defence Force' he is referring to both the willingness of this Parliament to exploit the loyalty of our armed forces and the willingness of ordinary but selfless Australians who will pay with their families, careers and lives for this Parliament's apathy and this Governments complacency. They represent just a few of the entries from my compilation of Labor euphemisms, myths and misrepresentations in the area of defence policy.

I conclude my brief remarks with reference to the unspoken claim to authority within this statement. The Minister is saying implicitly that all is well and on schedule with our defence forces-because he says so. I say to the Minister that his authority, credited to him in the early days of his ministry, was destroyed the day the Cabinet pulled the budget rug from under his feet and he came to this place and justified the Cabinet's decision. I say to the Minister that his authority will not be restored by parliamentary statements of 25 pages or more but by the restoration of real and substantial growth in the defence budget and by a fundamental reordering of his defence manpower priorities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAYDEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the course of the debate the Opposition has taken the opportunity of making some critical comments in some areas which are as much foreign policy concerns as they are defence preoccupations. Indeed, in one or two instances they are even more relevant to foreign policy than to defence. These relate to allegations of neglect in the Pacific area, cuts in aid, unwise allocation of aid funds to southern Africa and so on. The claims by and large are patently and demonstrably false, and I may come back to them later either when I make some other comments in this debate or perhaps on another occasion. But I repeat that the claims are patently and demonstrably false.

SPEECH.PARA: I start by saying that the practice of foreign affairs and the concerns of defence policy intersect at a number of points. The most critical and of course finally important point is when diplomacy breaks down and the defence machine has to take over. That means war and that represents the ultimate failure of our diplomacy. Of course, there is no suggestion we are anywhere near such a situation. However, this reminds me that the conduct of foreign policy, the diplomacy behind it, the way in which policy is developed, should therefore always be held up to critical scrutiny. There is no lack of that in Australia at any time. This is true at the moment. There are a number of quarters from which critical scrutiny is directed and that is appropriate.

There is, however, one quarter from which it is directed at present to which I want to address myself. This concerns the views which have been put forward by a former member of the diplomatic service, Dr J. W. C. Cumes, who has apparently written a book giving his assessment of a range of Ministers, Foreign Ministers, Prime Ministers and officials in his department. The previous Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, has been made to look something of an oaf in the chapter which apparently deals with him as condensed in one of the weekend newspapers. I cannot speak for Prime Minister Fraser but I will say this from my knowledge of him: He would not be as ill-informed, as inadequately briefed, nor as oafish as he is painted in that particular account. I also attract commentary of a rather severe nature. I offer no assessment, however, of the justice or otherwise of that. For all I know, it may well be a view of me which is shared by many people so I do not intend to explore reactions on that. However, if these views are to be put forward, and put forward as being authoritative views because of Dr Cumes's previous service in the diplomatic service of this country, I think for the sake of getting a balanced assessment of this matter, in particular to make judgment of his adequacy and his own objectivity to do so, there are some things I should put on the record.

The reports refer to Dr Cumes as a senior diplomat. He was senior only in the sense of having served in the Department of Foreign Affairs for a long time. He spent many years trying to rise above the third level of the Second Division and failed to do so. He failed to do so because of an unsatisfactory record in the service of the Department of Foreign Affairs. In respect of myself he has a particular reason for feeling some grievance towards me. When I became Foreign Minister I was advised very firmly by the previous Secretary to the Department of Foreign Affairs, Mr Peter Henderson, that under no circumstances should I allow an extension of service in The Hague, where Dr Cumes was head of mission, nor offer him, nor agree to any proposal from him that he be given, another head of mission. The reason, succinctly put to me, was: laziness and incompetence. It transpired that both in succession were put to me by Cumes and I rejected both. Cumes returned to Australia and he proposed that he should obtain promotion. His request and the proper processes he went through failed to achieve that promotion. Mr Henderson, true to his assessment of Cumes, refused to provide a position for Cumes in the Department of Foreign Affairs and he left shortly after, a bitter man.

In case it is thought that I have overstressed this let me give the House some quotes from the official files about Dr Cumes so that this assessment can be weighed up in an objective way. The selection committee that considered this application for level 6 appointment on 29 August 1984 reported:
. . . comments by three permanent heads under whom he has served raised serious questions about Dr Cumes' personal ability to meet the demands of a senior executive position in your Department.
Of course this being the Department of Foreign Affairs. The report went on:
We do not consider that Dr Cumes has the personal and professional attributes that would warrant further consideration on his application in competition with other candidates.

So much for this senior authoritative figure! Let me go back further. I have taken the opportunity of looking at his file. I quote what others say who objectively assessed him as professionals. As far back as 11 January 1957 a departmental assessor reported of him that `he does not willingly or rapidly switch his mind from one thing or another' and that `he is not suited to representational work'.

Nonetheless he did receive an appointment overseas. When one looks at the record one can only come to the conclusion that the Department of Foreign Affairs concluded in turn that it was better to have him overseas where he would be a nuisance in a small post to a small number of people than to have him in the Department of Foreign Affairs in Canberra where he would be a big nuisance to a big number of people. Shortly after he went to Brussels, the staff there were complaining of the stress that he was creating by his intolerable leadership and many of them were begging to be brought home. The Department, the file shows us, asked them to soldier on for the sake of the Department. In 1971 his assessor reported: `a rather difficult person to get on with'. A review of his head of mission administration on 26 June 1979 reported:
His working hours in the office are short and erratic as is his participation in the work of the Mission.

The report also said that he made `extravagant and selfish use of his privileges'. This is the authoritative and respected figure quoted so generously in some of the media and, I understand, currently appearing on electronic media.
In early 1979 at the United Nations Industrial Development Organisation Constitutional Conference, an Australian delegate complained that he, Cumes:
had not read the brief but insisted on laying down the law to the delegation, sometimes in ways that conflicted with the agreed Australian position.

It is a curious course of conduct for a man who presumes to be so authoritative and finally judicial in his assessment of the performance and qualities of others. Let me go on. It was reported by that delegate that the atmosphere in the mission was `dreadful' and that `officers at the mission had no guidance or sensible supervision from the Ambassador'. In 1980 a Deputy Secretary reported that it was stated that `Cumes has more or less given up work and that his mode of conduct will continue in the Hague'. His behaviour in respect of another senior officer was described as `childish and petty minded'. As it sums up so much of Dr Cumes and these finer qualities we are seeing recommended to us in the media recently, let me quote what this Deputy Secretary of the Department had to say on 25 March 1980:

There is nothing Dr Cumes loves more than lengthy and complicated correspondence arising from some ill-doing on his part. He is a skilled and prolific strewer of red herrings designed to shift the attack onto the person who criticised him last. It is apparent from X's-
a different X from the X I was talking about in Question Time today-

``in confidence'' report that Cumes has more or less given up work except when absolutely necessary and that this mode of conduct will continue in The Hague. I therefore see very little profit in your writing in detail to him.

My advice would be that you write him a very brief letter referring, but not in detail, to his widespread criticism of X. I suggest that you characterise it as childish and petty-minded and simply ask him not to do it again. I see little point in referring in a letter to the results of a PLV-
that is, a post liaison visit-

which took place as long ago as last June. I do not think your letter should say that there has been no personal criticism of Cumes. There were critical references in the open report from X and Y and a good deal of criticism in the ``in confidence'' report.

So much for this man who presumes to make these determinations on others! There is a note on file from early 1984 pointing out that the then Secretary Henderson had advised the Minister that Cumes was unsuitable for overseas posting and that Henderson did not want him back in the Department. The file records that Cumes was advised in early 1984 that `he was poor in staff relations' and that Cumes had denied this, responding that this problem arose `because the Department had not sent him the right people'. So you shoot the messengers, or some version of it. In about the same period as the level 6 application that I mentioned earlier, the Department reported:

Although critical of the Department's management, neither his comments nor his record suggest particular aptitude in this field. Along with this, comments by three permanent heads under whom he has served raised serious question about Dr Cumes's personal ability to meet the demands of a senior executive position in your Department. We do not consider that Dr Cumes has the personal and professional attributes that would warrant further consideration of his application in competition with other candidates.

What the record shows is simply this: Dr Cumes, for all of the pretensions he is engaged in, was indeed a personally vain and pretentious man, was a bully to the staff who worked under him at a series of missions, was incapable of good labour management of those unfortunate individuals, was lazy and uninvolved and was very much a failure. I quote from the official record and not my own sentiments that there is absolutely no evidence that this man is qualified to be passing critical let alone severely personally critical judgments on people who have given good service to this country-I exempt myself from this; others will make their judgment of that-such as my previous combative colleague, Malcolm Fraser, who as Prime Minister of this country certainly was not the oaf that Dr Cumes painted him out to be.

I should mention one other thing that Dr Cumes referred to in the account which appeared in a weekend newspaper. There is a suggestion that I suffer from some inferiority complex. I certainly do, and I think that is fairly evident not just as far as I am concerned but as far as anybody is concerned. No one who was self-confident and who had any commonsense would have spent as much time in this Parliament as I have. That is obvious and self-evident; I do not labour the point. The evidence he produced, however, was that I did not want to go to his home and that I objected very strongly when the car driver sought to take me there. The story is a little different. I resisted strongly Cumes's ingratiating efforts, nauseating as they were, to try to involve me socially at his home and with himself. I knew what his motive was-it was to try to establish some sort of rapport as a prelude to slapping onto me a demand to extend his appointment in The Hague and, if that failed, to get another head of mission appointment. I objected strongly, and rejected his proposition that I come to his home because I did not want to get drawn into this obvious and clumsy tactic he had adopted. I might add that I was in The Hague for about two days.

I should also say this about Cumes: all our missions overseas are important and The Hague is one of those important missions. So is Vienna, as was Brussels at the time he was there, though, much less important than it is now. All of them are important. But none of those missions are major missions and Dr Cumes was never asked, nor on the basis of what I see on his file is it ever likely that he would have been asked, to serve at any of our important major missions which do demand ability, dedication and energy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Almost one year has passed since the debate in this House on the 1987 Defence White Paper. It was an historic debate. It was an opportunity for members interested in the defence of Australia to discuss the first and fundamental duty of the citizens of a nation; that is, the defence of the homeland. The 1987 Defence White Paper was historic because it set out an achievable policy of self-reliance in the context of Australia's obligations as a member of the Western strategic community. We on this side of the House support the policy of the 1987 Defence White Paper. We support the policy of self-reliance. We of the Australian Labor Party have a proud history of supporting the concept of defence self-reliance and our alliance with the United States of America. In 1936 John Curtin told this House:

SPEECH.PARA: The people of Australia would expect this country to be capable of defending itself should the occasion arise.
He went on to say:
A greater degree of self-reliance in Australia's defence is essential.

We in the Labor Party fundamentally believe that Australia must, as soon as possible and in accordance with the nation's available resources, have a defence force that will destroy an invader and be an effective partner with the United States of America in the discharge of our obligations under ANZUS. By implementing the 1987 Defence White Paper, Australia is acquiring that capability. We shall go on to increase our defence capability. We shall continue to co-operate with our neighbours and assist them to help preserve the peace in our region. Nevertheless, our fundamental duty is to preserve, protect and defend Australia and its citizens, and we shall fight to the death in the performance of that duty.

Now that a year has passed since the introduction of the 1987 Defence White Paper it is entirely appropriate that this debate review the Government's accomplishments, the performance of the Opposition and the future of the defence White Paper. The strategic circum- stances obtaining when the defence White Paper was introduced have not changed for the better, the Soviet Union continues to expand its influence in the Pacific. This is in accordance with announced objectives of the General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, Mr Gorbachev. There has been no diminution of the Soviet military presence and power in Indo-China, the Soviet naval and air facilities at Cam Ranh Bay and Da Nang continue to expand. Not only are these facilities a potential dagger at the throats of South East Asia and Japan, but also they constitute a hostile counterpoint to the United States facilities at Subic Bay and Clark Field in the Philippines. If the United States military facilities were to be forced out of the Philippines, the whole security situation in the Pacific would be dramatically altered to the detriment of the Western alliance and the Association of South East Asian Nations. It would be a major turning point in the political, military and security situation in the Asian Pacific region. It would compel any future Australian government to an urgent revision of its defence policy and, I believe, to a dramatic expansion of the Australian Defence Force.

As a close friend of the Philippines, Australia has a responsibility to ensure that the people of the Philippines are aware of the enormous contribution their country makes to the security of the region by hosting the major United States facilities at Subic Bay and Clark Field. The security of Indonesia is a matter of vital concern to Australia. Now that a new government has been chosen in Indonesia it is imperative that Australia work diligently to improve relations with Indonesia. Both countries have friendly relations with the United States of America, and both countries are anti-communist. Both countries have an abiding desire for regional peace and stability, and I believe neighbours of both countries will look to Australia and Indonesia to adopt an increasing role in the maintenance of regional security.

It is a tragedy that speakers from the Liberal and National parties have during this debate criticised the Government's accountability in this House for its defence policy for this country. I am struck by what I believe to be the false lamentations of the Opposition and, indeed, of certain individuals in the Press about the defence policy of this country. A search through yesterday's Hansard reveals not one constructive suggestion from the Opposition benches in the debate-not one good idea, not one congratulatory sentence on the initiatives of this Government in building a better, tougher Australian Defence Force. That prompted me to make a brief investigation of the performance of the Liberal and National parties on defence policy during their term of office. I found that pay and conditions of service were a disgrace, not only for the service personnel but also for the people they were sworn to defend. In 1982 Defence Force pay was frozen by the Liberal-National Party Government. The Committee of Reference for Defence Force Pay had made a recommendation for an increase in the pay of service personnel. That recommendation was rejected by the Liberal-National Party Government.

Opposition spokesmen in this House have made much of the so-called separations from the Australian Defence Force. Even a brief examination of the record of the Liberal and National parties shows that on average 11 per cent of the Australian Defence Force left the service of their country annually. Yet there was not one mention of that fact in the debate from the Opposition and not one mention of what it did to arrest the separation rate of 11 per cent.

I turn to the Opposition's criticisms of this Government in deciding to re-equip the armed forces of this country. Equipment expenditure in the defence budget reached the dizzy heights of 18 per cent under the Liberal and National parties. Today the equipment component in the Defence Force budget is 29 per cent. This Government, with this Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), is providing the equipment for our service personnel to defeat and destroy an enemy and to preserve, protect and defend Australia. We are determined on that course. We are determined that there will be enough ships, planes, guns, ammunition, clothing and whatever else is necessary to equip the soldiers, sailors and airmen to win a battle that we may be forced to confront.

In contrast with the empty rhetoric of the Liberal and National parties, this Government is taking responsibility for relocating the defence forces to the northern area of our continent. The Government has decided to establish a northern command based at Darwin. The Government will locate a new fighter squadron at Tindal, provide additional patrol craft for the Royal Australian Navy, and provide Army regional surveillance units in the Northern Territory, north-western Australia and in north Queensland. The Army regional surveillance units, principally supplied by the Army Reserve, are being integrated into the Australian Army as part of the total force concept. That is to say, this Government has decided to use the talents and resources of both the regular Army and the Army Reserve to ensure that they have the skills of combat required of them successfully to defeat an enemy.

The Kangaroo 89 exercise will provide the 17,000 ground troops who will participate with an outstanding opportunity to hone those military skills which are now required of them and which will be required of them in the event of hostilities. Kangaroo 89 will also enable participation of Army Reserve units, particularly from the 1st Division, which includes Army Reserve units of the 11th Brigade, to ensure that they are able to gain experience in their new role of defending the vital northern installations, including ports and other important civilian infrastructure.

Not only must we be able to defend the approaches to our country as part of our participation in forward defence through our alliance responsibilities, but we must also be familiar with the northern part of our continent. We must know every inch of the ground there, and we must be able to fight in that country and, if we have to, we must fight to win. As part of the total build-up of defence facilities in the northern region of our continent, this Government, under this Minister, has placed a high priority on the development of a network of operational over-the-horizon radars. This is absolutely fundamental to ensuring that there is adequate long range surveillance of the northern reaches of our continent. I am confident that the requirement for airborne radar also will be provided by this Government, under this Minister, to ensure that that important part of our surveillance system is provided to the Australian defence forces as soon as economic circumstances permit.

The new submarine project is also of vital significance to the protection of the approaches to Australia. The shadow Minister for defence says that if the Liberal and National parties were to gain government, they would not cancel the submarine project, but one of the Opposition's most vociferous spokespersons on defence issues says that that is not so. The shadow Minister says that a Liberal-National Party government would want to acquire an aircraft carrier. I suggest that that would mean the cancellation of the submarine project. The six submarines being acquired by Australia will play a vital role in our defence. The eight Anzac ships to be acquired by Australia will also play a significant role in the defence of this country.

This debate is important not only because it provides an opportunity for members of the Government to express their commitment to the efforts of the Defence Minister in building up the Australian Defence Force, but also because it provides an opportunity for Opposition spokesmen to learn something about Australia's defence. It gives them a opportunity to make constructive suggestions on how to improve the Australian Defence Force. In the final analysis the soldiers of the Australian Defence Force wear the Australian khaki and the digger's hat. They do not wear the label of the Labor, Liberal or National parties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wind up the debate by thanking honourable members from both sides of the House for their participation. We have had several defence debates during the year, and I am glad to see that they attract a degree of interest in the House. I think there has been something absent from our consideration of the affairs of the nation because we have had few occasions over the last few years to debate defence matters here. Now that I am actually in a position to do something about it, I certainly shall.

SPEECH.PARA: A couple of points have been made that I think require a brief answer from me; I do not intend to use my full time. The shadow spokesman for defence, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), in debating my paper, initially made a series of claims about this Government's attitudes towards the pay and conditions of defence personnel. Those claims were more than adequately answered by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly). I think the fact that she was there, in a position to answer the claims, is an indication of the fundamental difference that is emerging between the Government and the Opposition in the treatment of defence matters. We have properly dignified that position by having a Cabinet Minister for Defence and an assistant outside the Cabinet. The shadow spokesman on defence is yet to make shadow Cabinet rank. I really think that when the time comes for some reshuffling of the various positions the Opposition should acknowledge the significance of the portfolio and accord it that rank.

The points that were made about defence personnel, of course, ignored the very extensive array of new benefits and new processes that have been put in place by the Government to ensure that the pay and conditions of service personnel both keep up with and exceed where necessary the standards that apply to similar professions in the civilian community. The runs are coming on the board for the Remuneration Tribunal, which handles defence matters, and in the broader areas of housing conditions, special allowances and support for families of defence personnel. They evidence the fact this Government takes the matter at least as seriously as, in fact a great deal more seriously than, our opponents did when they had the opportunity to govern. In addition, a number of criticisms were made about alleged gaps in the equipment vote. It is quite interesting that the criticisms commence by accusing me of being the Minister for defence equipment and then suggest, without indicating where cuts might occur, a plethora of additional equipment purchases.

That leads to the central weakness in the Opposition's position on defence. The Opposition spokesman on defence, the honourable member for McPherson, and those who support him in the Senate and in this House have not come forward with a defence strategy associated with a military strategy, a force structure or a reasonable costing. Those are the essential requirements of effective defence planning and policy. Until the Opposition has those, it is not really entitled to regard itself as having a defence policy at all. Despite the fact that there has been at least 12 months notice, there has been a remarkable lack of policy development from the Opposition. It is no good the Opposition coming into this House nitpicking through what may be errors or what may be regarded as areas of neglect in government policy if it is not prepared to pose alternatives. An Opposition defence spokesman who does that should scarcely regard himself, Cabinet rank or otherwise, as a defence spokesman at all.

Other Opposition members, and some members from the Government side of the House, dwelt on the question of Australia's relationships in the region. It was suggested that that matter was somewhat absent from the statement that I made. That suggestion was more than a little unkind, given the fact that only two weeks ago I delivered a somewhat lengthy statement on precisely that subject. Obviously it is not sensible that one should keep repeating things that one has said before.

What I say about that, however, is that one thing the Opposition has to acknowledge is that in the seven years of the Fraser Government essentially our position in South East Asia and the South Pacific was wound down. There may have been a policy rationale for that position that was adopted by the Fraser Government, but it is not a legitimate complaint to allege that our approach ignores those areas, in contrast with consideration by previous governments. I have only to cite the defence cooperation program in the South Pacific as evidence for that: $3m per annum was allocated when the Australian Labor Party came to Government, and $16m per annum is allocated now, which does not include what is given to New Guinea-which is a great deal more than that. The sum does not include the Pacific patrol boat program. What we have is a substantial contrast between the way in which the Government regards the South Pacific and the way in which it has been regarded in the past.

We have announced a series of measures to increase our activity in South East Asia. One Opposition spokesman in this House, and several members in the Senate, spoke of the Government neglecting the issue of the expansion of Indian naval forces and what that means for the development of defence policy in Australia. It is important that we set on the record that India is not and has never been an enemy of this country. India has not threatened and is not threatening our country's national survival. India has not at any point in time targeted a substantial Australian national interest and sought to interfere with it.

It is not the job of Defence Ministers or Foreign Ministers to wander around making enemies out of friends. That is not a sensible course of action to wish on a Defence Minister or a Foreign Minister. Prudence indicates that Defence Ministers ought to take account of all military developments that are occurring in the region and to ensure that in the development of Australia's defence posture the answer, if one is required, is to hand. Of course, we take note of all maritime developments in our region, whether originating from the Indian subcontinent or elsewhere. It is not sensible, however, for Ministers in a government to go into detail about those matters in the House when other diplomatic considerations are matters for obvious concern. Our requirement to maintain good relations with those with whom we have good relations ought really to be self-evident.

A further point ought to be made about this matter. Although it is true that India has a close relationship with the Soviet Union, and that sometimes that close relationship is spilt over into general issues on strategic policy, the fact of the matter is that India is quintessentially a nation on its own and a nation with its own perspective on world affairs. India is nobody's surrogate. Although from time to time there may be disagreement about the direction of that policy, it cannot be said in any shape or form that India is a lackey of the Soviet Union.

All honourable members in this House should be careful. Australia is a country which as time goes by is going to be expected to take increasing responsibility in this region, and we may find ourselves increasingly alone in this region. This will require a subtlety in our diplomacy that we have hitherto not exhibited, until recently, over the 80-odd years of our existence as a nation. If we reckon on being in this area for the next couple of thousand years, we are going to have to be a different sort of country in the area of diplomacy, foreign policy and strategic assessments for our defence policy than we have been in the past. I thank honourable members for their participation in this debate. There is a high standard of defence debate in this country and we should try to keep it that way.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
