SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am thankful, in more ways than one, for the opportunity to speak in this debate on the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill. It is appropriate as we are resuming the debate at this time to state simply the purpose of the legislation. As I am sure honourable members are aware, both the Government and the Opposition gave commitments during the last Federal election campaign to repeal the sunset clause in the National Crime Authority Act 1984. It is to give effect to that undertaking by the Government in its election program that the Opposition willingly supports this particular proposal, and as I mentioned earlier, the Opposition does so because the proposal formed part of its own policy objective at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: In the course of amending the Bill the Government has proposed a number of minor amendments to the Act to provide, in effect, for an extension of time for the Chairman of the National Crime Authority and to ensure also that those who have recently been appointed will no longer be appointed for four-year terms and will not be eligible for reappointment. In those circumstances people should be placed and replaced in sequential order so that there is some element of continuity in the membership of the Authority-so that experience will not be lost. Those arrangements seem sensible to the Opposition and were supported in the contribution of the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith).

The Bill provides also for amendments to the Telecommunications Interception Act to give judges who may consider applications for the issue of warrants authorising interceptions the same protection and immunity they would have if they were performing other functions conferred upon eligible judges-just as judges of the High Court of Australia have, in relation to proceedings before the High Court. That also seems to be an eminently sensible amendment which has the Opposition's support.

The purpose of the legislation is fairly narrow, but in the context of who has done the most to deal with questions of organised crime, we have had an element of debate. I must say that I thought it was largely a matter of academic interest, I suppose, but the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) who spoke before me raised the matter in terms of issue and did so in a way which I think distorted the record and history of the Fraser Government on the matter of organised crime in this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petty political point scoring.

—The shadow Minister says that it was petty political point scoring. If we look at the statements that were made, we can see that his comment is quite correct because even though they are not terms that I like to use about colleagues' contributions in the Parliament, I think the honourable member for McEwen grossly overstated the Australian Labor Party's record in relation to these matters and omitted very significant reforms put in place and initiatives taken by the Fraser Government. He did so by a wave of the hand and a suggestion that our proposals were not put in legislative form. I think he said that they were backed up by legislative proposals. The Government, because it put in place the National Crime Authority, believes it is the only body that has a record worthy of support in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: As I simply go through the number of areas in which the Fraser Government acted, honourable members can see how petty the points were that were made by the honourable member for McEwen. The first matter, to set the record straight, is that the Fraser Government set the foundations for cooperative Commonwealth-State action in the area of law enforcement. That was a new involvement for the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth had previously been involved in areas where it had specific responsibility under its area of legislation authorised by the Constitution and in terms of territories where it has its own police forces. But it is a very limited area in which the Commonwealth could act. What we saw were a number of positive steps taken by the Fraser Government.

The first initiative in 1980 resulted in the establishment of the Australian Police Ministers Council to promote a coordinated national response to law enforcement issues and to maximise the efficient use of police resources in this country. This was the first time that we had a Commonwealth-State committee to oversee nationally the fight against organised crime and to ensure that the forces of the States and the Commonwealth were involved in this effort. That was a pretty important initiative. It did not involve legislation immediately, but it certainly was a major step forward in involving the Commonwealth in a cooperative way with the States-something that the Government defends vigorously in terms of the way in which the National Crime Authority was established. It became the cause celebre later on, an area of difference between the Opposition which was prepared to go further and the Government, which was wanting to put a reign on the National Crime Authority to ensure that the States were involved in making references to it and to determine the areas of inquiry by the National Crime Authority.

This cooperative arrangement which the Government lauds was commenced with the Australian Police Ministers Council to promote this coordinated response. Again, in cooperation with the States, the Fraser Government was instrumental in the establishment of the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence. That occurred in February 1981. It also established a National Police Research Unit in May 1982. Surely it is not going to be said that these were not positive steps in the fight against organised crime. The honourable member for McEwen seems to be able to ignore these positive initiatives that were taken by the Fraser Government.

We also had a number of royal commissions. The first was the Williams Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs. Mr Justice Williams from Queensland, a very eminent lawyer, was involved in chairing that commission which brought forward recommendations which later resulted in many of the legislative initiatives that were followed up. We had the Costigan Royal Commission into corruption on the Melbourne wharves. The honourable member for McEwen in his own comments said that all the Fraser Government did was set up the Costigan inquiry to look into trade union activity. It was not set up to look at trade union activity, it was set up to look at organised criminal activity-corruption on the wharves of Melbourne in which some unionists were involved.

Honourable members will be aware of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union in particular that was referred to, but it was not an inquiry into trade union activity; it was an inquiry into the criminal activities in which some unionists were involved. That needs to be understood. The Costigan Royal Commission came across a wider level of activity in which some of those people and their associates were involved. It brought forward recommendations on the way in which this ought to be dealt with. We ought to be grateful for the work that Mr Costigan undertook in his royal commission. It was in that context that we came across certain legislative activity of the Fraser Government which, I can say truthfully, proved to be a very painful exercise politically. That involved the legislation to recoup unpaid company tax. The retrospective legislation to recoup unpaid company tax under bottom of the harbour schemes was directly attributable to the work of the Costigan Royal Commission and the McCabe-Lafranchi report in which the Commonwealth and the State of Victoria were involved and it resulted in legislation that the honourable member for McEwen would have us believe was not undertaken by the Fraser Government.

Lest it be thought that they were the only steps, I point out that we had the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into the Activities of the Nugan Hand Group and other matters. Of course, that is the same Mr Justice Stewart who now heads the National Crime Authority. We ought to understand that not only did the Fraser Government initiate those commissions and act upon the recommendations that were coming forward from them in a timely fashion, but also it was responsible for the introduction and passage through Parliament in 1982 of the National Crimes Commission Bill. I know as I was a participant in that debate. That legislation was not as enthusiastically supported by the then Opposition as this legislation has been supported by this Opposition, as we see in relation to the proposals that we have before us. The fact is that in 1982 the National Crimes Commission Act was not implemented because we had a change of government in March 1983. The Labor Party in office sought to water down-as I saw it and as I commented when we put in place the National Crime Authority-after certain conferences and discussions, some of the proposals that had been put in place in the National Crimes Commission Act. That was not the action of a government that was concerned about organised criminal activity.

I accept the speech of the honourable member for McEwen when he spoke more emotionally about his association as a former policeman with the National Crime Authority. He now chairs the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority in this Parliament that is involved in liaising with the Authority and reviewing the legislation in this area. I recognise that he has been on a learning curve, that he has had to acquaint himself, notwithstanding his former involvements with police forces, with the level and extent of organised crime in this country. I am glad that that learning exercise, as he put it, has opened a window to him to which he was not previously privy, so that he can view so much of this organised, internationally-associated criminal activity. I regret some of his comments, particularly in light of some comments made in the House today relating to the maligning of people because of their backgrounds and the countries from which they have come. Some comments implied that organised criminal activities had ethnic associations. I just comment that the prosecution records, even with the National Crime Authority, suggest that, of course, there are some circumstances in which international criminal activity leads to the involvement of some people of different ethnic origins. But, generally speaking, the record demonstrates that in percentage terms people from other countries are less likely than longstanding Australians to be involved in criminal activity in this nation.

We welcome the fact that the Government is prepared to commit itself to fighting organised criminal activity. The Opposition wants to see that those matters which have been raised in the annual report of the National Crime Authority and in its report on the Operation Silo investigation are taken up. I heard today-I was not aware before-that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has intimated that some of the proposals of the National Crime Authority may be picked up by the Government in time. I understand from the shadow Minister's speech that one of the amendments proposed by the Opposition may well be acceded to by the Government when the matter is pressed. I certainly hope that that is the case.

The report of the Operation Silo investigation by the National Crime Authority suggests quite specific law reform and administrative changes. I simply draw attention to those specific matters once more. The National Crime Authority was seeking to have the offence of giving false and misleading evidence before the Authority expanded so as to resolve the matters that might be dealt with. The report notes:

The provision requires the witness to address his, or in this case her, mind to the question of what constitutes a `material particular'. Proving the witness' knowledge as to materiality can be fraught with difficulties. The Authority has recommended that the section be amended accordingly.

That is a particularly important matter that needed to be raised by the Authority in the context of the charges that were brought arising out of Operation Silo. It is a matter about which, I understand, the Government is somewhat reticent in terms of its action on the matter.

There is also the question of the expenses of witnesses appearing on behalf of the National Crime Authority and the reimbursement of those expenses. That is a matter about which the Opposition will propose a significant amendment to section 26 of the principal Act. That is a matter well worthy of support, and one which we encourage the Government to accept. There is also the question of the investigation costs, which was raised by the National Crime Authority in its Operation Silo report. Those costs, which are significant, are detailed in the report. The matter of witnesses' expenses was raised in the context of the costs involved in investigating the offences involved in Operation Silo.

I want to make it very clear to the Government that, as part of its ongoing fight against organised crime, the way in which it acts on these recommendations of its Authority is an important measure of its commitment and performance. Clearly, the Government has had these proposals before it for some time. It has certainly had time to act upon them. I know that certain matters have been referred to the parliamentary Committee for review. We have had in the course of this debate advice from the Chairman of that Committee as to the way in which it is undertaking its review. It seems to me that, if the Government is serious about these matters, the National Crime Authority needs to have every weapon at its disposal in its armoury to ensure that it is able to meet organised criminal activity. It is not a matter for words; it is a matter for action on the Government's part. It has now been in office for over four years. The Government, in my view, must ensure that the effectiveness of this organisation is maintained.

There are certain further legislative proposals in relation to the proceeds of crime legislation and in relation to witness protection arrangements which the National Crime Authority in its more recent annual report also addresses. There are certain statements as to assistance that is sought in relation to listening devices legislation. The way in which the Government acts in relation to those recommendations of the National Crime Authority, in my view, will also be a measure of its effectiveness in and commitment to fighting organised criminal activity in this nation. I certainly encourage the Government to keep these matters firmly on its agenda or to risk the wrath of very firm criticism from this side of the House if it is found wanting in relation to those matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak in support of the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. This Bill contains amendments to the National Crime Authority Act 1984 and the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979. The Bill deserves the bipartisan support of the Parliament. It is a very significant Bill as it outlines some major amendments, the most important of which is to repeal the sunset clause, section 63, of the National Crime Authority Act 1984. The removal of this clause will guarantee the continued existence of the National Crime Authority (NCA) after 30 June 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased that the previous speaker, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), finds the amendments sensible. However, I take less kindly to his remarks regarding the previous speaker from this side of the House, the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland). I heard the speech by the honourable member for McEwen. He certainly was not being petty in his criticism, as the honourable member for Dundas suggested. The point made by the honourable member for McEwen was that the previous Government, the Fraser Government, when it came to dealing with organised crime, was very long on words, but when it came to legislative action its performance left something to be desired. Quite plainly, in terms of legislative action, this Government has the runs on the board. We have not merely talked about controlling organised crime. We have put in place legislation which will enable organised crime in this nation to be effectively resisted.

Another significant amendment in the legislation is the reappointment of Mr Justice Stewart for a period of one year. Over the past four years since his appointment as Chairman of the National Crime Authority, Mr Justice Stewart has made an important contribution to the National Crime Authority. We are fortunate that he has agreed to an extension of his appointment for a further year, which will allow the NCA to consolidate its position and go from strength to strength. The Bill before the House will also allow flexibility in the length of time for which members may be appointed to the NCA, thereby ensuring that people with the necessary qualifications and expertise, but who may not be in a position to accept a four-year term, are not prevented from accepting an appointment. This flexibility will enhance the operations of the authority and ensure that high quality applicants are appointed.

The first of the two amendments to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 will give eligible judges of the Federal Court of Australia the same protection and immunity applying to judges of the High Court of Australia. The second amendment will require the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police (AFP) to keep certified copies of warrants and instruments of revocation issued under part IV of the principal Act. These warrants authorise the interception of telegrams. The amendment will make it clear that part IV warrants and instruments of revocation are to be delivered to the Managing Director of Telecom Australia, with the AFP retaining certified copies.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in his election speech last year, foreshadowed the continued existence of the National Crime Authority. The legislation before the House gives effect to that undertaking. We all know that organised crime has spread its tentacles across the nation. Its progress has been largely unchecked, despite numerous royal commissions which have helped to uncover the extent to which it has been able to operate unhindered. In the report of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking, Mr Justice Stewart spoke about organised crime and the need for a national crimes commission. He said:
One of the striking facts concerning organised criminal activity in Australia is that it is seldom restricted to one State or to one area of a State.
He went on:

This Commission has not the slightest doubt that organised criminal activity is continuing which has not yet been identified by conventional law enforcement methods. Until the major figures are understood it will be impossible to do more than obtain convictions of the minor figures.
He continued:

A crimes commission that is continuously looking for patterns of action and association is far more likely to identify crime as organised crime than is the ordinary law enforcement agency. A national crime commission has the opportunity of monitoring activities which take place anywhere in Australia.

The Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union also supported the establishment of the National Crime Authority. There is no doubt that the NCA has achieved success in its fight against organised crime because it has been able to operate on a national basis and, one might say, even on an international basis. It has been able to monitor and investigate a plethora of matters with much greater expertise than has ever been achieved in the history of this nation. This was evident in the apprehension of Bruce Cornwell and Barry Bull, two major crime figures with a long history of drug trafficking, who were identified in at least three royal commissions and a Commonwealth-New South Wales joint task force on drug trafficking but who managed to evade normal law enforcement methods. The NCA investigation into those two men and their cohorts, codenamed Operation Silo, is a splendid example of what the Authority is all about, and certainly justifies its existence. Cornwell was sentenced to 23 years imprisonment with a non-parole period of 14 years, and Bull to 18 years imprisonment with a non-parole period of 11 years. In addition, a number of their associates have also been convicted.
Assets amounting to $3.2m were also seized. The NCA report on Operation Silo makes extremely interesting reading. I totally concur with the following comments in paragraph 5.17 on page 33:

The Authority accordingly considers that it has good grounds for regarding this investigation as a most successful endeavour. It demonstrated that a multidisciplinary team, comprising police, lawyers, financial analysts, and other support staff, can work as an efficient and effective group to achieve results which can only be regarded as outstanding and which would not have been achieved by normal police methods.

I draw the attention of honourable members to page 32 of the report, providing a brief assessment of Operation Silo, and in particular to paragraph 5.15, which is also worth mentioning in this debate. Part of the assessment reads:

Aside from exemplary police work, the investigation was also distinguished by proficient financial investigation work. In exposing part of the financial empire created by Cornwell with the assistance of well placed professional advisers, considerable flair and initiative was demonstrated by the Authority's accountants. The resultant pecuniary penalty proceedings against Cornwell and Bull represented one of the first applications made under the provisions of the Customs Act and certainly the first mounted on a major scale involving both interstate and overseas assets.

Those comments encapsulate the ethos of the National Crime Authority. Despite the initial controversy and torrid debate surrounding the establishment of the Authority, after almost four years of successful operation it has silenced its critics and more than justified its continued existence.

I turn now to the other achievements of the NCA. During 1986-87 the Authority made a number of significant seizures of illicit drugs, particularly heroin. Its investigations led to the seizure of 33 kilograms of heroin with an estimated street value of $36m. This is a decisive indication of the inroads the Authority is making into drug trafficking. I would also like to point out that the NCA's achievement rate in this area is substantially higher than all other law enforcement agencies and that the heroin seized is almost pure, which rather indicates that the Authority is catching the major importers before they have the opportunity to distribute the drug on the street. As at 1 January 1988, 226 persons had been charged with a total of 711 offences. Of 78 cases completed to date, 72 have resulted in successful prosecutions and a further three convictions obtained of persons who face further prosecutions. Charges against another 148 persons are pending. The bulk of those charges are drug related. Major offences, other than drug offences, successfully pursued by the NCA include the possession of firearms, passport and tax matters, murder, kidnapping and grievous bodily harm. Charges have been preferred against principal targets of major figures of six Commonwealth references and three general investigations, and include some well known underworld figures who had hitherto escaped prosecution.

As a result of the NCA's investigations to date, taxation assessments amounting to some $423m have been issued, and the Australian Taxation Office has been advised of a further $417.7m in undisclosed or undeclared income. It is important to note that the NCA's investigations into these matters have generally been the first to result in serious charges being laid, despite the individuals having been for several years the subject of allegations of criminal conduct. This demonstrates the important contribution being made by the Authority, because of the provision of special powers to enable it to investigate matters which have been beyond the scope of ordinary police methods.

It should also be emphasised that a key factor in the successful functioning of the National Crime Authority has been the Federal Government's commitment to cooperation with the States. All States and the Northern Territory have passed underpinning legislation which gives the NCA power to investigate State offences. Such cooperation through regular NCA intergovernmental committee meetings has resulted in several States granting references to the NCA under State laws. The 1986-87 annual report of the National Crime Authority pays tribute to the assistance the NCA receives from all State police forces. It has been able to second to its staff approximately 90 State police and specialised civilian officers. The performance of the NCA is monitored by the Parliamentary Joint Statutory Committee on the National Crime Authority which meets with the NCA at regular intervals.

There can be no doubt that the continued existence of the National Crime Authority is justified. It has more than proved that it is a powerful force against organised crime. Since its establishment in 1984, the NCA has achieved outstanding success against criminals in drug trafficking, white collar crime and corruption. In the words of the Chairman, Mr Justice Stewart, the National Crime Authority can look back on a record of achievement, and forward to continuing its work. The passing of this Bill will ensure that the National Crime Authority continues in pursuit of its primary objective of combating organised crime in Australia. I congratulate the Minister for this legislation. I have great pleasure in commending the Bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 2, clause 3, insert the following new clause:
`3a. Section 26 of the principal Act is repealed and the following section is substituted:
Reimbursement of expenses

``26. (1) A witness appearing before the Authority shall be paid by the Commonwealth in respect of the expenses of his or her attendance an amount ascertained in accordance with the prescribed scale or, if there is no prescribed scale, such amount as the Authority determines.

``(2) The Authority may direct that a person producing a document or thing pursuant to a notice issued under section 29 shall be paid by the Commonwealth in respect of the expenses of his or her attendance an amount ascertained in accordance with the prescribed scale or, if there is no prescribed scale, such amount as the Authority determines.'' '

The amendment proposes the repeal of section 26 of the principal Act and the substitution of proposed new subsections 26 (1) and 26 (2). Proposed new subsection 26 (1) is a restatement of the existing provision in the Act. Proposed new subsection 26 (2) brings forward a new provision which gives discretion to the National Crime Authority to allow the payment of expenses of attendance of an amount ascertained in accordance with the prescribed scale or, if there is no prescribed scale, such amount as the Authority determines. This amendment follows a recommendation made by the National Crime Authority in its 1986-87 report which was tabled in the second half of last year.

There has been a lot of talk in this debate about the respective merits of both sides of this chamber in terms of attitudes to organised crime and the capacity to get on with the job. One of the hallmarks of a government's attitude to any provision is the capacity for good administration, the capacity to dot the i's and cross the t's. In a sense this matter is of no great moment. I read from the annual report, which states:

The Authority has also made representations to the Commonwealth Government that persons responding to section 29 notices should receive appearance expenses along the same lines as witnesses who appear before the Authority in response to section 28 summonses. The Government is considering the matter.

To be considering the matter is not good enough. The Opposition says that this matter highlights the lack of attention to detail which we believe is necessary when looking to meet the demands placed on the National Crime Authority in the very important tasks it has before it. I am pleased that the Government will accept the amendment we have moved which essentially deals with this matter.

We have had a very good contribution to this debate, particularly from the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock). He brought the debate back into perspective. I have no doubt that it was the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) who coached the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) as to some of the things he said in his second reading contribution. I think the honourable member for Dundas and, I am sure, the Attorney-General will read the Hansard and go back over the debate to see what the honourable member had to say.

The substantive points made and the accurate reflection of the record of the Fraser Government lead to this fact: Fraser Government initiatives, in particular in promoting a joint State-Commonwealth approach to law enforcement, provided the momentum for the subsequent legislative actions of this Labor Government, which I was happy to give credit to in my speech during the second reading debate. I am happy to know that we have the support of the Government for our amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise for not being here in the earlier part of the debate. I was otherwise detained. I understand that the number of speakers on the speakers list was reduced. I was anxious to say a few words. I did not have to coach the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland). He has a natural ambition to oppose proposals put forward by the Opposition. For the benefit of my worthy opponent, I would like to put on record that the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union established the extent of criminal activity. We owe a great debt to Costigan in that, following the Costigan Royal Commission, the National Crime Authority was established. We also owe a great debt to Mr Justice Stewart because the National Crime Authority has clearly established the value of the work it does.

SPEECH.PARA: However, there are problems-we make that very clear-not within the National Crime Authority but perhaps in the police forces throughout Australia being able to understand the problems of the Crime Authority. I think the inquiry in Queensland will disclose matters which will make us very concerned about the extent of infiltration of criminal elements, not in relation to the Crime Authority but to other law enforcement areas.

I would like the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) to understand that the Government also deserves some credit for the fact that it has had to start bereft of any real effect of extradition treaties, which we are still trying to remedy, and of mutual assistance treaties, which we are eventually to get. For the first time in Australia, we will have the capacity to assist the National Crime Authority to pursue criminal activity which might take place in Australia but which could well be organised from outside Australia. That will require an element of continuity.

The honourable member is anxious that we all work together in this area. I meet with the State Attorneys. I pay them credit for their interest in guaranteeing that there is a unity of purpose between the Federal area and State administration. The State Attorneys are very well aware of the problems they have at times within their own jurisdictions. Having said that, I do not wish to delay the Committee further. The amendment which has been moved, which I understand has been amended in a suitable way to relate to expenses, is quite acceptable to the Government. DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' ENTITLEMENTS (MAINTENANCE INCOME TEST) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 March, on motion by Mr Howe:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements (Maintenance Income Test) Amendment Bill 1988 is a very important piece of legislation because it goes to the heart of one of the major social problems facing Australia today; that is, the very high rate of divorces and marriage break-ups and the resulting impact that has on the economic and social lives of many hundreds of thousands of Australian children. Before I go into the detail of the Bill I would like to draw the attention of the House to allegations made by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) in answer to a question yesterday. He alleged that child support was an area where there was no common ground between the Government and the Opposition. I want it to be quite clearly understood that I refute absolutely that suggestion.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister is well aware that not only did the Opposition support amendments to the Family Law Act late last year but we have supported all three of the pieces of legislation which have so far been introduced into this House in regard to the new family income, family maintenance and family support packages. Therefore, for the Minister to suggest, as he did yesterday, that the coalition policy to put non-custodial parents who do not pay maintenance into gaol was the sum total of our policy is absurd in the extreme. It is perhaps what one would expect from a very frustrated Minister who is now facing the situation where every Labor seat in New South Wales north of the Hawkesbury River is now in the hands of the Liberal and National parties. On those figures the Federal Government would lose all its seats in the area. I hope that Government members who are not present in this chamber, regrettably, but who I hope are listening to this debate, are aware of the fact that people in the community of Australia that previously regarded themselves as being Labor supporters are no longer prepared to support Labor. With swings of up to 17 or 20 per cent in some areas the Labor Party has every reason to be concerned.

Having got that off my chest, I turn to the basis of this legislation. The Opposition's family policy was initially released on 21 December 1986. We stressed in that policy the need to improve the present system. We said:

We will amend the Family Law Act to restore the primary obligation of parents to maintain their children, while confirming that support will continue to be provided for families in need. A fair, effective means of determining and enforcing maintenance payment by non-custodial parents for their children will be established and income sourced where appropriate.
We went on to say:

Many parting couples are abdicating their responsibilities towards their dependants, shifting the burden of family financial support from themselves onto taxpayers. Large numbers of single parent families live in poverty. Social welfare expenditure on them by the Commonwealth has risen dramatically as a result.

That policy has been consistent and we are pleased that the Government has taken over our policy as its own. But I think the point should be made that when we attempted to introduce private member's legislation into the Senate to cover the essential ingredients of that package it was the Government which voted against our attempts to have this legislation introduced. Consequently, on behalf of the Opposition I take great exception to suggestions by the Minister that all we have as a policy is to put defaulters in gaol, if I may use his words.

Senator Durack introduced a private member's Bill in December 1985 to address the problem of judicial failure to determine adequate maintenance payments and to enforce fulfilment of the orders. Despite the Government's stated intention to introduce similar reforms, in a demonstration of exceedingly bad grace it voted against Senator Durack's Bill in May 1987. Now the Government has finally implemented these policies, it has naturally been supported by the Opposition. It is a sad day when the Minister must misrepresent an area of policy where there is substantial common ground on both sides of the House. The working relationship between his office and mine in this area has been excellent and it is a credit to staff members in his office who have worked closely with those in my office. It can be demonstrated by the smooth passage of this very significant legislation on no fewer than three occasions to date. Maybe the Minister gets out of bed on the wrong side occasionally but I take grave exception to his coming into this House and grossly distorting the situation.

This Bill is part of the stage one package of measures to provide for the introduction of the child support scheme. The objects are to ensure that those parents who have a capacity to pay do not abandon to the social security system the financial responsibility of supporting their children and, secondly, to increase the numbers of families receiving maintenance, to increase the level of their maintenance and to ensure that it is received on a regular basis. The Bill details the interaction between the child support scheme in terms of social security recipients, specifically by changing the way in which maintenance is treated in social security arrangements. Other measures in the package are the Family Law Amendment Act of 1987 and the Child Support Act of 1988. As I have stated, we have already supported them.

The basis of the Bill covers some very complex but nevertheless important areas. The Bill provides for an income test on maintenance income in addition to and separate from the existing income test applicable to pensions, benefits and certain allowances which were previously paid to custodial parents on behalf of their children. Maintenance will no longer be treated as part of the existing income test and therefore increased maintenance payments will not impact upon other income and act as a disincentive to the receipt of income from other sources such as employment. Maintenance income would include payments of cash maintenance, provision of in-kind benefits provided by way of maintenance and transfers of capital. The definition will explicitly cover maintenance collected and paid under the Child Support Act of 1988. The cause of the payment or conferral of benefit may be a court order, a registered agreement or otherwise.

The second area covered by the Bill is in-kind maintenance income. This is defined as maintenance income not consisting of a payment received by the pensioner and covers, for example, a spouse or former spouse paying school fees in respect of a child of the pensioner allowee. The annual value of those school fees would be taken into account. If the in-kind maintenance income were health insurance premiums, the annual rate of those premiums would be assessed. Should in-kind maintenance income be in the form of payment of electricity or gas accounts, the Department would estimate a reasonable annual value of that benefit based on all the known facts.

Should in-kind maintenance income be in the form of housing, much would depend on the ownership of the house. The in-kind housing maintenance would be assessed as nil where the house was owned by the pensioner, beneficiary or allowee either alone or as a co-owner. Should the house be subject to a mortgage in the name of both pensioner or beneficiary allowee and spouse or former spouse, any mortgage payments by the spouse in excess of one-half of the total payable would be assessed as maintenance income. Should the house be subject to a mortgage in the name of only the spouse or former spouse, the value of in-kind maintenance would be an amount reflecting the value of the right of occupation by the pensioner, and should the house be leased, all rental payments by the spouse or former spouse would be assessed as maintenance income.

The third element in this trifecta is capitalised maintenance income; for example, the transfer of capital amounts for maintenance purposes and indirect payments of maintenance over $1,500. This would be maintenance income not received on a periodic basis. Examples of capitalised maintenance would be the payment of a lump sum of cash, the settlement of shares or securities, or the settlement of a house provided by way of maintenance. Capitalised maintenance income would be apportioned over a period of time. During that period the person would be taken to receive the apportioned maintenance income in fortnightly instalments.

Amendments to the Family Law Act include a provision to specify capitalised maintenance over a period. So if the amount has not been specified over a period or there is no court order, the Bill provides a method whereby, firstly, if it is child maintenance, it will be apportioned over the time from the date of receipt of the maintenance up to the child's eighteenth birthday or, secondly, if the income relates to the maintenance of a service pensioner, the apportionment will be from the date it is received until the recipient is aged 65.

The Bill also provides for a free area, that is, an amount which pensioners can receive before reductions in pensions occur. This free area is substantially less than that provided for other beneficiaries of the social security arrangements and is, in fact, limited to $15 per week, plus an additional $5 per week for a second and subsequent child, dependent on the maintenance recipient, in respect of maintenance income. Maintenance income in excess of the free area, that is, in excess of $15, would reduce the pension, benefit or allowance by 50c per dollar. This is, as I said earlier, lower than the free area which applies to the existing social security income test in which a single parent with one child is entitled to $52 a week and the withdrawal rate is the same as for existing income tests.

The hardship provisions in the Bill, which can best be described as special maintenance income, provide that the rate of pension, benefit or allowance will not be reduced by more than 25 per cent of the maximum rate if maintenance income falls into one of three categories. These include: all in-kind maintenance paid to a pensioner, beneficiary or allowee in the first six months following separation from a spouse or former spouse; in-kind house maintenance provided in some cases; and maintenance income provided in relation to the expenses arising directly from a disability of a child of the pensioner, beneficiary or allowee.

One area of concern or interest in the Bill is that of transitional provisions. The Bill provides relief for certain existing pensioners who might otherwise lose, or face a reduction in, pension, benefit or allowance as a result of the new maintenance income test. This is to meet the Government's commitment that existing pensioners or beneficiaries would not have their total income reduced. The transitional provisions cease to apply to a pensioner when total income rises above that received in the final pre-amendment period.

The Bill also provides a set of conditions for reasonable action which has to be taken by custodial parents to demonstrate that they have taken whatever action is regarded as adequate to obtain maintenance. The Bill also clarifies the requirement that those who wish to qualify for a widow's pension or a supporting parent's benefit must take reasonable action to obtain maintenance where maintenance may be payable. Reasonable action is not defined by the Bill, but is at the discretion of the Secretary to the Department of Social Security. Guidelines for reasonable action are set out in the Department of Social Security manual of instructions so that the condition requiring reasonable action to obtain maintenance is met where: the claimant has instituted court proceedings in the matter; a court has refused to make an order or if only a small amount has been awarded; voluntary maintenance is being paid; the claimant does not know the whereabouts of the other parent of the child; legal advice is to the effect that the court would be unlikely to make an order; the other parent of the child is a pensioner or beneficiary; or the name of the father of the child is unknown. In addition, it is the Department's policy that there are circumstances in which it would not be reasonable for a claimant to take action, for example, where there is fear of violence from the other party, where there is other concern for the safety or health of the claimant or children; or where action may be a cause of disruption to the domestic affairs of the father or mother of the child. The Bill does not change these guidelines but no doubt this will be an area which we will have to watch very carefully to ensure that people do not try to use the escape clause merely as a means for getting access to pensions without taking adequate action to get payment from the non-custodial parent.

Whereas the existing section 47 of the Principal Act forbids only the grant of pension in such a case and is unclear as to whether the maintenance in question is for the widow or sole parent only, or for the widow and any dependent child or children, the proposed substitute section would clarify that the obligation to take reasonable action to obtain maintenance would be a continuing obligation; that failure to fulfil the obligation would result in cancellation of the pension; that the obligation would result in cancellation of the pension; and that the obligation would apply to action for maintenance for both spouse and child. I support this because it means that whereas a payment may be deemed to be payable on a specific date that does not remove the long term responsibility of a custodial parent to take whatever appropriate action that parent can take to be able at some stage to identify the father or the mother, as the case may be, so that proceedings can be taken through the family maintenance arrangements to ensure that the contribution is payable.

In terms of the actual contents of the legislation, the Government claims that these measures taken together-that is, the arrangements following amendments to the Family Law Act and the Child Support Act-will give a net gain of $120m in 1988-89 and $192.8m in 1989-90 and there will be further savings beyond those financial years. As I said, we are slightly sceptical about that level of financial gain but to a great degree it will depend to what extent officers of the Department of Social Security, at the counters where they actually have to test the cases, are prepared to apply the measures in a rigorous manner.

Another point worth making is that the Government claims that there will be no losers in this. Unfortunately there will be losers, at least for a relatively short period. Its commitment is that existing pensioners will not have their total income reduced to below what it was prior to the introduction of the scheme. As I said, this will not be met. This is because the benchmark used-that is, the amount received prior to the scheme-will not be indexed over time. For example, in six months if a pensioner who now receives a total income of $118 per week had stayed in the old scheme that amount would be increased with the consumer price index and would be worth slightly more. Under the new scheme the pension will not be adjusted up to the new figures; it will be adjusted only to the original $118 and the pension would thus lose value at the current rate of inflation.

It is claimed by the Government that an estimated 25,000 recipients who currently receive some maintenance will be affected by this in the first six months, declining to 5,000 within 12 months and to only about 50 or 60 within 18 months, according to the Minister's office. However, approximately 30 per cent of current special pension beneficiaries and widow B recipients will not receive any additional income as they have no prospect of receiving maintenance. For example, the non-custodial parent may be dead, unemployed, not known or cannot be found. The Government has made no commitment, despite the savings it will obviously make, to give further assistance to this group.

The points I have made emphasise that this legislation is significant. The Opposition is supporting the thrust of the Bill, as we should, because matters such as this should not be the subject of political division and controversy. Having said that, however, I move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`Whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House deplores the fact that the economic and social policies pursued by the Hawke Government since March 1983 have directly contributed to the continuing high level of marriage break-ups by:
(1) increasing the number of Australian families living below the poverty line and bearing the brunt of unemployment, including an additional 165 000 children;
(2) pursuing policies which have resulted in single income families on average weekly earnings with 2 children facing a decline of $42 a week in their standard of living in real terms;

(3) abolishing negative gearing between July 1985 and September 1987 which resulted in a decline in rental accommodation, and a steep rise in rental costs which has contributed to 160 000 Australians waiting for public housing, while thousands of families and individuals live in refuges, emergency accommodation or on the streets;
(4) failing to give recognition to the increased burdens of families with dependants other than the approximately 23% eligible for assistance under the Family Assistance Scheme; and
(5) contributing to a marked decline in the standard of living of veterans, war widows, ex-service personnel and serving personnel'.

Government members may regard that as somewhat of an omnibus motion but I think it demonstrates quite clearly the genuine concern of the Opposition, and the political events of last Saturday demonstrate most conclusively that standards of living in Australia have fallen and are continuing to fall and that there are large segments of our population who have always been underprivileged to some extent or other but who are possibly more underprivileged today than since the days of the Great Depression. It is the fundamental responsibility of the Government to put in place policies which overcome those problems. Unfortunately, the electorate now believes, with reason, that over the last five years the Government, being a Labor government, has not lived up to the promise the electorate obviously expected of it.

I turn to some statistics to back up my second reading amendment. The proportion of people divorcing in a year who have previously been divorced has increased rapidly since 1981, when the figure was approximately 9.4 per cent among both divorcing wives and husbands. In 1986 it had grown to 14.3 per cent among divorcing husbands and 13.5 per cent among divorcing wives. The number of divorces granted in 1986 totalled 39,400 and, while it is true to say that there has been some decline in the growth of divorces since that peak following the passage of the Murphy Family Law Act, nevertheless the figure is most unsatisfactory and one has to face the fact that while one cannot keep families together, for obvious reasons, there is a range of economic factors over which government policy does have some impact and which in turn are contributing factors to the very high level of family breakup in Australia today.

It is worth noting, in terms of the impact on children, that 45,200 children became dependants of persons divorced in 1986 alone, and there are hundreds of thousands of children affected if we take into account the total number of divorces over recent years. In 1986 the divorce rate was highest in the 30 to 34 age group, in which the rate for males was 12.2 per thousand, while the rate for females in the 25 to 29 and 30 to 34 age groups was 12.6 per thousand. These figures are a graphic indication of the fundamental breakdown of the social institutions which are the very underpinning of our society.

While nobody should stand here and try to make judgments about the social environment and the reasons why individuals get divorced, one has to say that wherever possible government policy should not be directed at encouraging or increasing the number of divorces in Australian society, because of the major impact divorce has on children and the fact that most of these people then become part recipients of social welfare benefits for much, if not most, of the rest of their lives. One has only to visit, as I hope the Minister at the table, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), has, some of the crisis accommodation facilities around Sydney to see that, for example, male children over the age of 12 are forcibly taken from their mothers-because the mothers go into female refuges while the fathers often have to go into male refuges-and slotted off in a similar direction. They are living with people who are social misfits of varying degrees-drug addicts and people with alcohol problems, et cetera. How can we expect the children to come out of such an extraordinary environment as normal citizens?

The sad fact is that since the 1970s the funding of family support facilities, including family crisis accommodation, has been totally unsatisfactory. The result is that welfare organisations such as the Smith Family, the St Vincent de Paul Society and the Sydney City Mission have had to carry a gross amount of the cost, including the administrative cost, of servicing programs which clearly have their genesis in government policy. Unfortunately those policies are simply not appropriate today. The result of all this is that child poverty in Australia now affects 825,000 children-one in five children-an increase of 165,000 since Hawke took power in 1985. The Government's family allowance supplement policy will alleviate some of this, but even if all families who are entitled to receive the FAS take it up-and at this stage it looks as though only about 50 per cent will do so-that still means that some 450,000 children, or 45,000 in South Australia alone, for example, will be living below the poverty line. The number of children whose parents are dependent on social security increased in the 10 years from 1975 from 7 per cent to 18 per cent-a figure which requires the deepest consideration by all members of this House. We find the figures at that level in all the States, and the situation is particularly bad in the more populous States of New South Wales and Victoria.

I refer now to unemployment in families. Analysis of Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) figures by Dr Peter Whiteford of the Social Welfare Research Centre of the University of New South Wales shows that in 1986 more than 220,000 children, or 5.2 per cent of all Australian children, were in families whose chief wage earner was unemployed. In 1986 more than 500,000 people were in families whose chief means of income support was the unemployment benefit. As a proportion of the unemployed, unemployed people with children increased from 37 per cent to 46 per cent between 1980 and1986. Most of those years were years of Labor government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what your leader says all the time.

—It is a statistical fact. Since 1982 the greatest proportional increases in unemployment rates have been for families with three or more children. Families have borne the brunt of unemployment despite an overall trend of reduced unemployment. For example, from 1985-after Labor had been elected-to 1986 the total number of unemployed persons fell by 8,000, as we get told every day by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke); but the number with dependants-this is the important point-actually increased by 13,000 and the number of children in families with an unemployed head increased by a further 22,000.

SPEECH.PARA: What is worse, the most difficult part of all this to reconcile is the length of unemployment. People with family responsibilities have experienced, and continue to experience, longer durations of unemployment since 1982-83. The mean duration of unemployment and the proportion of married men who have been unemployed for more than a year have increased dramatically. In 1986, 53 per cent of all men unemployed for more than a year were married, compared to 45 per cent in 1982. Thirty-eight per cent of long term unemployment beneficiaries have three or more children. Of course the FAS will be of some benefit to these people, but what I am simply saying is that there is still a large body of poor people, people who earn even around average weekly earnings, with large families who face great difficulty. This is a major area of poverty, and I am glad to see that the Minister for Social Security has now come into the chamber. No doubt he will defend himself at the appropriate time. These are the issues the Government has to face up to and it is because it has not done so until its fifth year in office-I emphasise that point; it is its fifth year in office-that it now wonders why its traditional political base has eroded before its very eyes.

I turn now briefly, in my last few minutes, to the increased burden on families. An average family needs a further $42 a week to restore its disposable income to what it was in March 1983. There has been an increased tax take over the last five years. Family allowances and dependent spouse rebates have in fact fallen by about 30 per cent in real terms. Interest rates, home loan repayments and housing waiting lists have all risen dramatically, and middle Australia has been the victim since this Government took power. The rich are earning a greater share of the income and middle income earners are earning less, according to comparisons of household disposable income put out by the ABS from 1981-82 to 1985-86. The $23 billion family debt crisis is also a direct result of the Labor Government's policies, which have taxed Australian families into poverty. The full impact of the Government's erosion of the relative tax position of middle income families is shown by the fact that each family is now carrying an average debt of $6,000 to banks and lending institutions-a 40 per cent increase over the last 12 months. According to Father Kevin Caldwell, the National Director of the Australian Catholic Welfare Commission:
The broad picture does not seem to be getting any better for the great majority of families.

The newest projections of the Commission suggest that by June 1988 the position will be worse for most families than was forecast nearly two years ago, in July 1986. At that time it was estimated that a breadwinner on average earnings with a dependent spouse and two children would have experienced a decline of 4.6 per cent in family income since 1976-77. The revised estimate is that the cumulative loss of income will amount to 7.5 per cent or nearly $40 a week by June 1988. This figure is likely to underestimate the loss for many families since it does not take account of the cuts to tax rebates for health and education or the effects of higher interest rates over that period. A family on average weekly earnings with five children, for example, will be able to keep only 90.4 per cent of its income as of June 1988, even after the family allowance supplement, compared to the 96.8 per cent of its income it was allowed to keep in 1976-77. Such a family will be $33.66 a week worse off.

I turn now to the problem of homelessness. The St Vincent de Paul Society in Sydney's west, one of the regions worst hit by unemployment and an area which voted so strongly against Labor last Saturday, has demonstrated that it is turning away four people for every one to whom it can offer assistance. In fact, it is now receiving requests from an estimated 1.4 million people annually. The same problem applies to the Sydney City Mission, the St Vincent de Paul Society, as I said, the Smith Family and the Salvation Army. There are now over 160,000 people on public housing waiting lists, with home loan interest rates rising by 3 per cent to 15.5 per cent as a direct result of this Government's economic policies, although fortunately they have now fallen. The Government is also responsible for the decline in housing investment because of the disincentives to investment, particularly the earlier decision to cut and then reinstate negative gearing, which has contributed so much to the rental crisis in the past. The issue is quite clear. This Government, in a very belated manner, after five years in office has finally discovered that there are poor people in Australia who have a right to expect some support from it. I only wish that more had been done earlier.

Another problem that is worth repeating is that in 1985-86, and the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) confirmed this, the New South Wales Government cut emergency cash assistance by $6m. It then said to the welfare organisations, `It is over to you'. Those organisations have written numerous letters to this Government asking for some support in solving the problem, but the responsible Minister, the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) does not even bother to answer their correspondence.

SPEECH.PARA: I highlight to the House that this then, in turn, leads to some interesting phraseology and drafting of the very important explanatory memorandum-I think XM is the public servants' nomenclature for that particular document-which is used by so many in the veterans' constituency, in the social security area, the Australian Council of Social Service and beyond in the interpretation and understanding of this legislation. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements (Maintenance Income Test) Amendment Bill 1988. A number of points need to be made in justification of this Bill. It is a Bill which is greatly overdue. Everyone who has spoken in this debate so far has made that point quite clear. Whilst the Opposition has signalled its intention of amending that part of the Bill relating to the automatic collection of maintenance by the child support agency, which, as has been pointed out, is quite inappropriate in relation to the Bill that is before the House, it does support the Bill in principle. I am very pleased to hear that that is so. Of course, we had to listen to the usual diatribe from the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), supported by the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer). The honourable member for Farrer, of course, wears blinkers, and tends to see things purely in terms of veterans' entitlements. I respect his interest in that area; nevertheless, the majority of his comments failed to address the Bill. Fortunately, the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) put the record straight in his excellent speech.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of children in poverty in this country is a serious issue. They are in poverty because so few non-custodial parents pay maintenance. The Department of Social Security has stated that 70 per cent of non-custodial parents do not pay maintenance. Marjorie Barrett, a spokesperson for the Campaign for Economic Justice, has stated that the figure may be as high as 90 per cent. Of course, this is a matter for further investigation. Nevertheless, the figure is immensely high and the bare statistics cover human tragedy and human suffering.

This social problem has been getting worse in the last 10 years. This is proven by the fact that there has been a 70 per cent increase in sole-parent families. The proportion of sole parents in receipt of a pension or benefit has increased from 65 per cent to 85 per cent. In addition, government expenditure on pensions and benefits for sole parents has increased by over 200 per cent in the past 10 years. There are now more than a quarter of a million sole-parent families, with 450,000 children, who are forced to rely on pensions and benefits from the social security system. Yet it is quite clear from both the research and the anecdotal evidence in this area that in the vast majority of cases the non-custodial parent is employed and would be able to contribute to the support of his or her children.

It is against this background that the Government, in line with its commitment to ensure that by 1990 no Australian child should live in poverty, has introduced the child support scheme. This Bill reinforces the previous legislation in this area-the Child Support Act-which established a child support register, a registrar and an agency which ensures that maintenance is efficiently collected from those who are liable to pay it and that maintenance is distributed to the families entitled to receive it. In addition, amendments to the Family Law Act encourage more substantial awards of maintenance than have been customary previously.

It is fair to ask: What is wrong with the existing child maintenance system? I venture to suggest that every member of this House has been confronted with constituents who have been seriously disadvantaged by the present system. There are four major criticisms of the present system. The first is the inadequate level of existing court orders. Under the current system maintenance orders are made at the going rate of approximately $25 per week per child, or $40 per week for two children. By any standards these payments are totally inadequate and lead to the need for social security support. The second major criticism is the issue of the inadequate coverage of the population. As I have pointed out, at least 70 per cent-or at most 90 per cent-of non-custodial parents do not pay maintenance. The third major criticism relates to the difficulties experienced in enforcing court orders. That criticism has been ventilated in this House on numerous occasions, as well as in the Family Court of Australia. The custodial parent and the child are the losers in that situation. The fourth major criticism is the lack of integration of the child maintenance system with the social security system. As the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) said in his second reading speech, the Bill will bring into account a wide range of maintenance income paid to social security and veteran pensioners and beneficiaries.

The Bill before the House deals essentially with the fourth major criticism, the lack of integration of the child maintenance system with the social security system. Maintenance can be split into three distinct and separate categories. We tend to think of maintenance as being a cash transfer from the non-custodial parent to the custodial parent. That is one category; the second category is maintenance in kind; and the third is what can be termed capital maintenance. Maintenance in kind includes such items as food and household items supplied, payment of health insurance, the provision of housing or payment of rent, payment of household accounts, educational and child care expenses, and motor vehicle registration and running costs. Capital maintenance includes the transfer of a substantial lump sum of capital, which sometimes occurs in the context of distribution of property following a divorce.

The new maintenance income test will take account of in-kind maintenance payments as well as payments of capital. From the perspective of equity, it would be unfair for cash payments to affect the level of pensions if other forms of payment such as capital transfers, usually more available to wealthier people, those protected by Opposition members, did not do so. It is proposed, and I strongly welcome this, that in-kind and capital maintenance will not be allowed to reduce penalty rates by more than 25 per cent of the maximum rate where this maintenance is to maintain the children and the custodial parent in the family home-for example, rent or mortgage payments-or where the maintenance is provided because of an illness, disability or learning difficulty. A 25 per cent reduction limit will also apply to in-kind or capital maintenance provided for any other reason, but only for the first six months after separation. The Minister also proposes in this Bill another very important exception that will limit the impact of the new maintenance income test. For recipients of a pension, benefit or allowance there is a special savings clause so that their total income-that is, from the pension and all other sources-cannot be reduced below their pre-scheme level of income while they are eligible for any pension, benefit or allowance.

These changes in the way maintenance is treated in relation to some income-tested social security pensions and benefits will not affect family allowances or the family allowance supplement. Pensions, benefits and allowances not currently income tested will also not be affected. For these payments there will be a new, separate income test to take account of any maintenance received. This will help to relieve the burden on taxpayers. The community will benefit because the Government is attempting to shift the burden of supporting the custodial parent and children back onto those non-custodial parents who in the past have been shirking their responsibilities. In 1986-87 the cost to the community of sole parent pensions amounted to $1,886m. That is money that could be spent on other social justice programs, if a way can be found to ensure an adequate income for those now dependent on a sole parent pension. For example, that money could be spent on public housing or a host of other social justice programs. Everyone accepts the need for such programs in Australia today. The Bill also seeks to encourage sole parents in receipt of maintenance income to increase total income by seeking other forms of income, especially income from remunerative employment. As the previous speaker, the honourable member for Farrer, said, there will be two income test free areas in the Act: one will affect maintenance income and the other will apply to all other types of income. The advantage which flows from the receipt of both general and maintenance income is an area totally free from any income test, and considerably more generous than where one type of income is received.

Finally, it must be emphasised that this Bill is stage 1 of the child support scheme and sets out to overcome the worst of the problems that have been encountered to date. The aims of stage 1 are to increase substantially the number of sole parent families receiving child maintenance payments; to help ensure that court orders for child maintenance are enforced; to help ensure that maintenance payments are received on a regular basis; to provide for more adequate levels of maintenance payments in court maintenance orders made after the start of the scheme; and to relieve taxpayers of their substantial burden by ensuring that non-custodial parents accept a fair share of financial responsibility for their children. I therefore support the Bill before the House and reject the amendment moved by the honourable member for Bradfield, on the ground that it is irrelevant.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Brunswick to Richmond Powerline-The Funnies-Lyne Electorate: Removal of Public Telephones-Political Reporting: Standards-Taxation Treaty-Medicare-Burra Area: Roads

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being approximately 7.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted. I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise the controversial issue of the Brunswick to Richmond powerline-a 220,000-volt-line that the Cain Labor Government wants to erect over seven Melbourne suburbs. The issue is controversial because the residents do not want it; the unions are unhappy with it and have placed bans on parts of the project; two senior Federal Government Ministers-the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) and the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe)-are not happy with it, presumably because it runs through their electorates; the State Opposition in Victoria is vehemently opposed to it; and even one of the commissioners of the State Electricity Commission of Victoria (SEC) wants the plans changed. Last weekend the people of Kew clearly indicated that they do not want it. It is a powerline that the people of Melbourne do not want.

SPEECH.PARA: The State Labor Government and the SEC press on, hell-bent on ignoring the swelling ranks of opposition, and are pushing ahead with construction-a State Labor Government which, like its Federal counterpart, has completely lost touch. The Victorian State Government wants to build this line-a $15.2m, eight-kilometre powerline that will be erected overhead on poles 28 metres or nine storeys high. In some cases these poles will be 32 to 33 metres high in parkland areas. On an aesthetic level, this powerline is grossly ugly but, more importantly, it poses serious environmental and possible health risks.

This powerline will cut through the unique, natural bushland of Yarra Valley, Merri Creek Valley and, in particular, Studley Park, areas where the State Government has ploughed millions of dollars into restoring the natural vegetation and upgrade recreational facilities through tree planting and landscaping. This precious and valuable asset must be preserved. In a major policy statement for urban Melbourne, entitled `Shaping Melbourne's Future', released last year, the State Government made a commitment to protect Melbourne's urban parklands from industrial developments by ensuring that in the future they would be `appropriately sited and controlled'. Obviously, this commitment does not apply to the SEC powerline project. So much for the rhetoric of the Cain Government.

The Cain Government continues to ignore the concerns of residents. Up in smoke will go the many hours of voluntary labour that residents of the Yarra and Merri Creek Valleys have devoted to caring for this sensitive and fragile environment. The Cain Government's professed priority for the environment and conservation is a sham.

Very importantly, we have a Federal Labor Government Minister stating that the Cain Government's plans are unacceptable. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is reported in a local newspaper, The Progress Press, as saying:
The alienation of the Yarra River Valley in an area which is deficient in open space, is quite unacceptable.

Today this Federal Minister, immediate past President of the State Australian Labor Party, is reported as calling for the Victorian Government to stop work on the powerline at the same time as he has announced his candidacy for the Australian Labor Party Federal President. The situation could not be more serious for Mr Cain. There is a clear, deep split and fundamental difference between the State and Federal Labor parties-with at least two Federal Ministers in open conflict with the State Government. The Party is in chaos in Victoria as it is in New South Wales. Labor is falling apart in Victoria. It seems that both the Cain Government and the SEC lackeys are blind to the sensitive and unique areas of native vegetation which will be destroyed forever with the construction of the powerline.

Let us consider what is happening. Already the precious native grasses at Dickinson Reserve have been substantially destroyed. Needless to say, the powerline poles are visually intrusive and will be highly visible along ridges of Merri Creek Valley and Yarra Valley. At least the present powerline is tucked into the landscape. I mentioned earlier the health risks of such a high voltage powerline. A United States radiation expert, Dr Jerry Phillips, has said that `constant exposure of high voltage power lines could increase the risk of cancer 12 times'-not a very comforting thought for many residents who will have to live close to the lines. Quite rightly, the residents have called upon the State Government to halt the construction of the powerline until a detailed medical study of the effects of electro-magnetic radiation is carried out.

The Brunswick to Richmond powerline is yet another example of a Labor government losing touch with its constituency, its base, its own party and unions, and importantly, residents in Labor-held electorates. It is a Government that simply churns out the rhetoric but, when it comes to protecting a great community reserve and valuable asset-the Yarra and Merri Creek Valleys-it does nothing to demonstrate its concern and commitment for urban conservation and the environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Vandals.

—They are. The Cain Government, with its arrogant and dictatorial style, like the former Unsworth Government in New South Wales, like the Hawke Government, can no longer understand or relate to the needs of the ordinary man and woman-the needs, hopes and aspiration of people. Instead, the Cain Government makes its policy in isolation and then forces it on the residents with little, and more often, no consultation.

SPEECH.PARA: I call on the Cain Government to get back to basics and act in the interests of the people. The Brunswick to Richmond powerline must be stopped. I call on the Cain Government and the SEC to defer construction of this powerline until a thorough investigation of the environmental impact and associated health risks is undertaken. It will be a disaster if the powerline proceeds as proposed. I repeat: the Brunswick-to-Richmond powerline must be stopped.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that, on the surface, the reasons appear to be justified, but I want to put up a very strong argument that we have not reached the stage in Australia when we should allow such a service to be obliterated by the department or government concerned. The local people value their public phone within the community because many of them still do not have the phone connected. In case of emergency people in the area need a public phone. There are breakdowns of other phones within the community, breakdowns of vehicles, deaths or cases where emergencies arise and a nearby phone is required.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the dairy farmers?
