SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 July 1982 the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) Committee on Fiscal Affairs approved a Draft Multilateral Administrative Assistance Convention on Tax Matters. That was formally opened for signature by OECD members on 25 January 1988. The Federal Labor Government is favourably disposed toward that classified convention although it has not yet signed it. Indeed, it supports the principle of exchanging tax files on Australians with other foreign tax authorities. Under this convention Australia would be compelled to provide a requesting country with almost all information relating to the taxation contributions of individual Australians and companies. This is a most frightening proposition with very widespread implications. The `tax treaty' will oblige the Australian Government to swap not just tax file numbers but complete tax files. Furthermore, Article 5 of the tax treaty states:

SPEECH.PARA: If the information available in the tax files of the requested State is not sufficient to enable it to comply with the request for information, that State shall take all relevant measures to provide the applicant State with the information requested.

In other words, if the information requested of Australia is not contained in the Australian Taxation Office files but is held elsewhere, the requesting country has a right to access that information. Article 12 compels requested States to take action to recover amounts of tax or to take conservancy measures, even if the claim is contested or it is not yet the subject of an instrument permitting enforcement. Quite obviously, Article 12 has enormous potential dangers for our system of justice which is traditionally based on the common law.

In the explanatory report of the Convention mention is made of the exchange of information by way of computer tapes. This would seem particularly to pertain to the articles covering the automatic and spontaneous exchange of information. In effect, what will result from this is a databank of staggering proportions being built up at the OECD's headquarters in Paris-a databank accessible to all other signatories of the treaty.

Article 22 contains the secrecy provisions for the tax treaty. However, in all seriousness, how can Australians rely on the confidentiality of foreign nations when our own Labor Government is unable to guarantee confidentiality within even one Government instrumentality? The latest evidence of this was the action of the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) in handing over to the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) confidential information containing medical provider numbers.

Australians need to ask this Labor Government why they are seriously considering signing this tax treaty when Australia is already a signatory to a treaty of mutual assistance in criminal matters. This clearly covers taxation offences to the extent that they prima facie constitute a criminal offence. In addition, existing bilateral agreements between OECD member nations satisfactorily cover the matter of double taxation. Why then do we need to go further and implement the proposed tax treaty at a cost of many millions of dollars? Australians also need to ask why, after the recent defeat of the insidious ID card, the Labor Government is conducting essentially secret negotiations to weaken further the privacy of Australians on an international as well as a domestic basis. Australians need to ask why this arrogant Hawke-Keating Government has not informed them about this classified tax treaty and why copies of it are not readily available. I might add that even the OECD is loath to make copies available.

Already a number of other countries have expressed grave reservations because they consider that it goes too far in infringing the privacy of their citizens. Furthermore, they consider that it contravenes the European Convention on Human Rights. When threatened with the ID card Australians were moved to decisive action in a manner rarely seen in relatively conservative Australia. I urge Australians to mobilise again to prevent another attempted betrayal of the right to privacy, a right won only after centuries of struggle. A fundamental freedom of our liberal democracy will be forever lost if the old autocracy of feudal barons is supplanted by the new tyranny of international bureaucracy.

SPEECH.PARA: The main reason I wanted to speak tonight was to raise another issue which I think is significant in my electorate. Last Monday I had the opportunity to open officially the Mudgee Medicare branch office. It is one of six offices that are being opened in New South Wales at present to extend further the quite comprehensive network of Medicare branch offices throughout the State. To the people of Mudgee the opening of this office means that they will have access to the full range of branch facilities and claims services. A fully-fledged Medicare branch office is obviously able to process a greater variety of claims and ones of much higher value than was possible under the old agency arrangements that prevailed and will prevail until the end of this month.

The Health Insurance Commission which administers the Medicare system is fast gaining quite a justifiable reputation for its awesome efficiency and ability to achieve customer service satisfaction. I point out to honourable members that in the 1986-87 annual report of the Commission it is indicated that the average turnaround time for all Medicare claims, other than those paid in cash, was only 4.6 calendar days. This figure was well within the very stringent target limits set by the Commission of five working days for the processing of Medicare claims.

It is little wonder then that the services offered by Medicare are so highly regarded by the public. A market research survey conducted by the Commission in May 1987 found that the overall customer satisfaction with the Medicare claims payment service had grown to 94 per cent. I believe that any business that deals with the public in such large numbers and can claim this level of customer satisfaction must be getting it right. The main reasons given by those satisfied were the efficiency with which claims are handled, the fast service and prompt payment, the helpful staff, and the simple, straightforward procedure.

The other interesting point is that community support for the Medicare program continues to grow despite some attacks that we see from time to time in this House by those opposite. Community support for Medicare has grown by another 3 per cent to 64 per cent. Interestingly, only 15 per cent of those surveyed believe that Medicare should be abolished. I think it is more important to note, however, that a high level of satisfaction with the way Medicare claims are handled was expressed by both the supporters and the opponents of the program.

All I can say about the continuing opponents of the program is that they do not fully appreciate the vital reasons for introducing Medicare. As we all know, prior to Medicare two million Australians had no health insurance cover whatsoever. Many of those people were middle and low income earners who decided to run the risk of going without cover rather than pay the premium.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were the most vulnerable.

—When they became sick or injured, they would often face massive medial and hospital bills. As my colleague the honourable member for Streeton commented, often these people were the most vulnerable in the community. Medicare ensures that no one who needs medical or hospital treatment will be denied it on the grounds that he cannot afford it. I believe that the figures in the survey speak for themselves. Given the level of support for Medicare within the community, I believe that it will go from strength to strength.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, upon notice, on 16 February 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How long has the drug Genotropin, which is manufactured in Sweden and used in the treatment of sufferers of Turners Syndrome, been under evaluation by his Department.
(2) When will his Department make a formal recommendation as to whether the drug will be available in Australia.
(3) Has his attention been drawn to the many people who are awaiting the decision.
(4) Why has the decision taken so long to make.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Data on the drug Genotropin was received for evaluation on 3 March and 6 May 1987. Genotropin is not marketed anywhere in the world for use specifically in patients with Turner's Syndrome. However, it is being investigated as a treatment for the short stature which is associated with this disease.

(2) The Department will make a formal recommendation about the commencement of Australian clinical trials with the drug in Turner's Syndrome, once company answers (sent on 18 February 1988) to remaining questions have been examined.

(3) There is another growth hormone available on the market in Australia for proven growth hormone deficiency states. Any patient with Turner's Syndrome for whom a physician believes investigational use of growth hormone is warranted, therefore has access at the present time to such therapy.

(4) A full evaluation of a combined general marketing and clinical trial application for a new drug cannot usually be achieved in less than one year. There is every indication that this target will be met for Genotropin.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 February 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say what are the goals and functions of the World Bank's Multilateral Guarantee Agency.
(2) Has the Government joined the Agency; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The main objective of the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA) is to encourage the flow of commercial investment for productive purposes, mainly from developed countries to developing member countries of the World Bank, by guaranteeing investments against non-commercial risk; e.g. currency transfer risks, expropriation, war and civil disturbance and breach of contract by the host government.

(2) Australia is still considering whether to join the Agency, pending clarification of MIGA's actual operations, including its relationship with national agencies such as AUSTRADE/EFIC. MIGA is expected to come into operation shortly. The initial estimated cost of membership to Australia would be about $A5 million.
